 ++Best voxel based building system hands down. Ability to combine pieces gives buildings extremely high customizability and sleek ergonomics +Dynamic destruction and advanced physics engine make destroying things just as fun as building them+Creation of medieval inventions such as catapults, drawbridges, elevators, and whatever else you can come up with.+Modding and workshop support for sharing creations --Complex worlds and complex destruction cause massive lag, even on higher end machines -No mode outside of creation yet, survival still a ways off-No multiplayer as of yet-Some types of contraptions are buggy and can break themselvesIf you are into voxel creation games and you can deal with some optimization and minor structural integrity bugs you will have a blast with Medieval Engineers. If you are more into survival and PvP hold off until they add multiplayer and survival, because the building system will perfectly compliment that kind of gameplay.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								Please note this review is dated during the Early Access of this game and is subject to change I will do my best to update it when I see fit.Medieval Engineers is a great building game with a ton of promise. I've never personally experience a better voxel system for quick and intuitive building. The game makes creation extremely easy and with the dynamic destruction and physics of it's engine it makes even mistakes or intentional destruction beautiful. On that note this game is very process intensive, demolishing huge castles will lagg even the best of PC's and in it's current build I have crashed quite often. That being said the act of building is spot on and in my honest opinion a very solid base for pretty much ensuring this will be a successful Early Access title. The game needs more content, that's a given, you are limited to what you can build because of lacking tools especially in the spring and rope territory. But with it's unique voxel construction system you can build blocks inside of blocks so if you're creative you can make some absolutely wild stuff in this early build. Be careful though the game does have a very decent structure system and if you don't build your castles with weight in mind they definitely can come tumbling down.Overall in it's current build I give it 7/10 but with updates to the game engine (latency), added materials, multiplayer enabled and survival mode implemented I can seriously see this game being in the high 9s.I don't want to be intrusive with videos but I am makign a series breifly overviewing a lot of the games core mechanics you can watch any at your viewing pleasure.Building Basics

content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								As of this writing, the Planets (more like Planet) update dropped, 0.3.1.After nearly six months of hiatus, a lot of things have changed.Under the management of Tim (deepflame), the company has, in my opinion, turned the entire game development around.The game is moving to a sane patch schedule:Every week: Alternating between bugfixes and new minor content (like blocks)Every 6-7 Weeks: Minor feature release (like mechanical blocks)Every 3 months: Major feature release (not sure what this entails, but probably on planets scale)Now, on to the new features:Planets:- This is more like a single planet, but can be fully modded for any size or features, just like in Space Engineers.- Contains ruins and other neat easter eggs.- Yes, you can walk all the way around a planet!Survival research system:- Yes, survival is actually playable now. The default world is still creative, but survival does work. You can now gather resources, including rock on the road, and use them to build components to build blocks.- You start out with nothing. You no longer get starter tools. Minimalist survival experts rejoice!- Building increasingly more complex blocks requires advancing in the research system to unlock higher tiered blocks and tools.Female Engineer:- This may be concerning for some players, like "why spend time on a female engineer when there are more gameplay elements that should be worked on first?"- In my opinion, having a female playable character in the vanilla game is important for gaining playerbase. People want to have a character that represents them. Gaining more playerbase is always good for a healthy game. People want to play as a character that they feel represents them. For example, I'd prefer a non-bearded model myself.- Mods can handle this, and there are some already, but it's not the same as having the vanilla game support it. Many players only play a game for 30 minutes or so before they decide whether they like it or not. Having that choice up front, without having to learn the modding system, will help people feel more comfortable with the game.Claim Blocks:- You can now claim square areas with a claim block. This protects your area from unauthorized building and mining inside the claimed area. Note this does not protect against normal attacks.- Taxes: You have to pay taxes (in the form of resources) to maintain the claim block and keep your area claimed.Banners:- This is, in my opinion, one of the most immersion providing features to this game. It's well known that in medieval times, banners of the Lord or King who owned an area were on display, and carried into battle. One common example is Cross of Saint George used during The Crusades. Now you can make your own banner and show off to enemies who you are before you destroy them!World Map:- This is my most favorite feature.- The map shows you not only world features, such as mountains, trees, and roads; but also player constructed buildings and rough player location. The map updates dynamically based on player creations (but not voxel changes).- The world map is automatically generated based on the height map used to construct the planet. This means planet modders don't have to do anything special to create a map, it will be created on its own.Fast Travel:- Used in conjunction with the map, this allows the player to quickly travel around the planet, subject to customizable limits (can also be turned off completely).- Analogous to the Jump Drive in Space Engineers.Contextual Menu:- They are still a work in progress, but they are vastly improved over the old clunky interface.There are so many more features and fixes.As for function:- Multiplayer has improved quite a bit, and at least for servers with 16 players or less, is actually playable.- Yes there are bugs, but they are working quickly to stomp them out now.- UI is still clunky in some places (like inventory), but more improvements are coming.- There are issues placing blocks, particularly when trying to aim them to place.Summary:- Has the game improved? Tremendously.- Is it perfectly playable? Of course not, it's still alpha. That said, it's more playable than before.If you are concerned about EA games and aren't impressed with what you've seen so far (why?), then hold back and wait for a few more updates.However if you are as excited as I am about where this game is going, and what is in the game now, then pick it up!Under Tim's leadership, this is really turning out to be a fantastic game. I hope Space Engineers gets the same love and guidance as Medieval Engineers is now getting.

content:
Posted: January 8
Early Access Review
								The 'Now with Planets' update to Medieval Engineers turned it from a Early-Access Alpha into a truly playable game. The content of the game DOUBLED with the Farming update and even added a clear line of progression to the Survival game mode. I state this so that potential players reading this can get an idea of how much different the game has become in just a few months.The Good:Great little sandbox game. You can build amazing structures as well as devices to help you build or to demolish. For example when I am gathering wood, I use a cart that I designed to help bring it back, effectively quadrupling my inventory space.Visuals of the game are pretty good. Looks clean but still keeping with a rustic feel. IMO it looks more 'Roman' than Medieval. But this might be due to the fact that the peasant's ain't got shtuff all over them.Audio is pretty good. Sounds are clear and the music is soothing and ambient mostly. Barking deer is a bit weird. No they don't bark like dogs, they sound like deer but the noise they make makes them easier to find since they get a bit noisy when they get close.Weekly updates either fix bugs, add new content for us to tinker with, both, or sometimes add major changes that impact the entire game. Its always neat to check back on Tuesdays to see what was changed.The Bad:As an early access game in Alpha, it lacks content. Its a sandbox game without any campaigns or scenarios. When you first load in, you won't know what the heck to do. You've gotta just pick a goal and go with it.For survival, the little content in the game (establishing a base camp and farm to sustain yourself) is a bit grindy. Part of the game is simply trying to get yourself situated so most tasks are made easier by constructing mechanisms or simply building up raw resources and the containers to store them. This can get a bit grindy and monotonous.I said the sound is good, before and I still stick to that. But I do have to be honest and say it still has some placeholder stuff. Again its alpha and that is just a polishing issue I'm sure will get fixed eventually, obviously a low priority.The Ugly:Peasants don't work. They are supposed to be little workers that help move stuff around for you. They broke in the Planet update.Barbarians spawn... randomly. Even inside your claimed areas if there is a large enough grass area. This means they can even spawn inside your walls if you walled off a large flat area. They also can spawn nearly on top of you in some cases. They make for interesting foes, and even a source of materials (their weapons can be broken down for ingots), but I recommend leaving them turned off until you're established. If it was like in Minecraft where you had better control of when and where they spawn through ingame measures (like claimed areas restricting their spawn) I'd move this to a good feature.I almost don't want to mention this last one as its probably going to be fixed very very shortly. But the Multiplayer has its issues. Players connected to a host will see interesting placement issues and other oddities. The most glaring issue, inventory desync was fixed four days ago so that is great. Reason I say that the rest will be fixed is Space Engineers just got a fix to its MP issues. ME will be getting that same fix very shortly, maybe even in a few days of this writing. So don't let this issue be the one to dissuade you.Overall:The game is great for what it is. The gameplay is solid. The bugs are few and far between. The game as an early access is doing quite well. The development team that was restructured a few months ago has done a phenomenal job. My biggest complaint is there's not enough of the game yet. But that is surely being worked on. I play ME just about every other day and my favorite part is playing it every Tuesday to see a new set of bugs squished and new content added.If you're looking for a sidegame to add to your library, that will surely evolve over time to be something more. This game will do well by you. Its also a great game to hook up with a few friends on MP (even with the current issues) and work on larger build projects together.I'm hoping in the future when all MP issues are resolved there will be more MP servers available for larger amounts of players to go head to head, Roleplay, or just dink around with community builds. It definitely has potential and I have faith that it will get there. ME has my recommendation.

Posted: March 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Coming from my experience in Space Engineers, and seeing what they already have accomplished with this game, it will easily become my favorite game of all time. I can't express how much I have already wanted to invest (despite time constraints with real life obstacles) in this game. It is the game I have always wanted, finally coming true. You may describe it as Skyrim meets Minecraft for those too lazy to add a new game to their vocabulary. Perhaps is the barbaric form of Space Engineers, but to me it is much more. I wanted a game like this from my childhood on, and finally it has arrived. It does a disservice to the creators of the game to try and morph it into a "child" or "combination" of already created and known games. This game deserves to be in your vocabulary and known from this day forth as Medieval Engineers. If anything, use this game as a basis for future hybrids.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is an Early Access game, so I can only judge this game by its updates (frequency, value of the updates, etc). Before I do this, I have to warn those who actually want to have tons of fun with this game: This game is actually not really enjoyable at all (at least not for me). Game mechanics are broken, physics on self made war machines are bugged and sometimes your creation will just explode, even if you have no spring or something attached to it. Also controls are weird. So if you expect this to work as good as - lets say Besiege - you should wait a few more months. And then you should remember that Medieval Engineers is or will be more realistic than Besiege.BUT Keen House Software, well known because of it's first 'Engineering'-game Space Engineers are updating really frequent with content updates and bugfixes. In the last week they fixed incredibly much and new content was also added to the game. And there are still huge updates for Space Engineers (planets confirmed, yayy!). So if you want to have a good game in the future, if you are aware this is an early alpha and if you want to test the (incredibly good) destruction engine, you should pick it up now.

								The planets update was a step in a direction. It could be forward, backwards, or a side step. All the new features from the planets update are really cool, although I miss being an engineer. I had visions of game being more like it was in the pre-alpha days, more mechanical. I am aware of performance issues this may cause. Of course all of this is still possible in the current state of the game.tl;dr being an "engineer" is no longer required

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Update 4. march 2015: New patch today/yesterday introduces breakable ropes and rope hooks that can release a rope at a certain angle (perfect for making trebuchet siege weapons). The breakable ropes snap at contact with another block, a barbarian or the player. This is excellent news and gives a lot of possibilites! A great creative physics playground just got even better.The ability to remove broken blocks automatically is also added and makes repairing a castle much easier. No more walking into broken blocks to push them out of the way in order to place a new block. Thank you Keen Software House!! Saves so much time when your ridiculously high "princess tower" collapses for the third time!Also added was the ability to switch between day and night in creative mode, so you can see your pretty castle with torches and other light sources in the dark. Very pretty! My dream castle became even more wonderful in the dark :-)They also made a rudimentary survival mode that makes you die if you fall down too high or get stuff in your head (like blocks, barbarians clubs or artillery projectiles). So far, they are keeping their "patch every tuesday" promise. 11/10---Original review below---This game is going to be brilliant. Already it is incredibly fun, despite it being a very early and unfinished game. There are quite a few bugs (to be expected from early access), so if dealing with that is something you absolutely loathe I recommend waiting a bit before trying it. Knowing the developer after playing a lot of Space Engineers, they make patches and improvements all the time. Normally I am skeptical to all early access games, because you always fear it will turn into vapor ware and be abandoned, but I had no such reservations about this one.Since release there have already been several patches and hotfixes, including one today that gave us more blocks to play with, including more catch blocks (essentially hinges), round timber logs, as well as "barbarian" bots that basically run around the map looking for king statues to destroy. This is excellent news for those of us who enjoy making horrible medieval traps of all kinds (dev has a hilarious video showing this). The bots can be turned on or off depending on what you want to do, so they don't mess up your perfect dream castle if you don't want to.Even with all the current limitations and bugs, the game is already amazingly fun to play. Keep in mind though that it does require a bit powerful pc to run properly. Especially destruction of blocks can slow down the computer.Finally, a tip: If ropes, rope drums, hinges or physics in general start acting strange, try saving and going out to main menu and reloading the game. It sorts out most problems.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Perhaps the most enjoyable sandbox I've played since Minecraft..for the 3 hours I managed to play it, at least.The building mechanics are intuitive and for the most part easy to use, and the destruction engine is reminiscent of Red Faction: Guerrila. If you want to understand that last part, watch someones video on YouTube.However, whilst I do recommend this game it is only in the hope that the developers will improve on this. The game is perhaps the most unoptimised I have ever played, with lag occuring almost every time you destroy something. The game also lacks a large number of objects to build with. It would be even better if it had a Besiege swing to it, with AI that actually moves, interacts etc. My PC isn't the best, I will be using an i5 as of tomorrow, which may combat the problems with FPS drops during destruction, but what really is disappointing is I can no longer play the game. My graphics card does qualify above the recommended requirements, but now whenever I try to play the game I am given an error. After trying the troubleshoots people have come up with it still doesn't work, and I hope that the developers will get back to me with a solution. I do believe it is because my graphics card uses Nvidia's Kepler microarchitecture, which struggles to use DX11.1. So, 7/10 in the hope that the developers grow this game, optimise it, and solve the issues people are having with DX11.1.#Edit: 2 hours later, it's been fixed, I can now play. They've added multiplayer and sounds. Best game ever.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								I like to go in blind, so I started out with in survival mode with everything at whatever defaults the devs thought best. Here's my experience so far:I awoke in a rather picturesque field of grass and flowers next to a cart. I pushed the cart and it moved easily, which seemed like good news, but I'd save that for later. I immediately headed for a forest I saw in the distance as that looked like a good place to start my search for useful resources. Arriving at the edge of the forest I immediately grabbed the axe I had conveniently been provided and chopped down a tree. The tree fell on me and I died.I awoke again next to my trusty cart and headed in a different direction. This time I wandered until I came across an abandoned house. It wasn't the most interesting thing I'd ever seen, so I wandered back toward the forest. Noticing my growing hunger, I looked around for food and saw an unsuspecting deer. I tried to get the deer. The deer ran away. I searched some more and found some mushrooms. At this point I was quite hungry so it seemed worth the risk. I ate the mushrooms which turned out to be nothing more than edible mushrooms. I wandered back to the tree I had chopped down and tried to pick it up. Apparently a 175kg log wouldn't fit in my backpack, so I chopped it into smaller pieces and carried them back to a relatively level area in the field to start building some shelter.The game is absolutely not done, and a cursory glance at the forums will show you a definite weak spot in project management, resulting in a somewhat unstructured and chaotic release cycle. To their credit, they specifically list Project Manager as an open position, so I think they're aware.The bottom line is this game is fun in its current state, and promises much more. If you like survival, building, medieval times and being crushed by falling trees, this game is absolutely for you.10/10 would be crushed again.

								I preordered this game and initially was disappointed.Things have changed.This is now one of my favorite medieval games. Early Access Review
								Space Engineers set 200 years earlier...Took me and my mate over 2 hours to try and construct just a tiny shelter in survival. After so much frustration (and hilarity at our own failure), we gave up.Surprising how poor this game is compared to it's big brother (Space Engineers). What's wrong with it? Well...- You need to eat more frequently than Jabba the Hutt, else you starve and die.- You can't move stones to build stuff, so you have to build where they fall.- How the hell do you put a goddam roof on four walls!? - Frequent random / weird deaths - Chops tree, walks into chopped wood, dies...wtf?- Loads up new game, wanders into wood, finds random NPC running towards me. Gets killed by NPC with a club...eh!?- Building anything is so fiddly it hurts- Dreadful controlsIt's like the dev's tried to do something different, got fed up and decided to concentrate on Space Engineers instead (which is a far better game)May get better in the future, but for me it's a "no" at the mo.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								April 2017: Have a bit of imagination and make this review slightly more positive, but not too much, I am saying that only because they started growing a sense of humor lately, not because they added pulleys, for they did not. <-- YES THAT'S WHAT WE ARE WAITING FOR, PULLEYS, not you not adding pulleys.When I bought this game, not so long ago (october 2015), multiplayer was stable and there was much to do. One day later, a patch came in, and multiplayer was not stable anymore, and it has not improved since. But on the plus side, the more patches comes, the less there is to do. Give it a few years and you will be able to place a prefab building, no more cluttering of your toolbar with useless things like foundations, walls, stairs ... give it ten years and you will be able to do nothing.This game is a pearl where patches get rid of things you can do and add bugs.Well it is almost playable again, not entirely but you can have fun for 2 hours in multiplayer building things and then 2 hours destroying it with client-vibrating siege engines. Yes, it still is glitchy but maps works at least.The development pace is way too slow though. with maybe one significant patch every 9 months, it will only take 12 more years until that one reaches puberty, 18 until you can play with it.Here you go cpt, I updated the date, and yes I tried the content days ago, it's a step in a direction, I am unsure if it's the right one though, the rest remains very current and I am trying not to mention your UPGRADE to DX 11.1 which♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off greatly, especially since W7 patch for dx11.1 is just a compatibility upgrade and not an upgrade at all.-I will attempt to describe how the game goes:Build something for 2 hours.Sometimes it crumbles, so extend that duration by 2 additional hours.Build a siege engine, no, not a battering ram, it won't work. Not a ballista, it will fire 5 metres in front of you. build a trebuchet, it's easy. takes 10 minutes.now choose one of three options:Singleplayer: FINE but repetitive.Multiplayer as server: Same.Multiplayer as client: Said trebuchet will vibrate as if it was possessed by some evil spirit, eventually disintegrating itself after a while, usually it will have killed you first if you attempted to tame the beast. Double the fun if you made it rotary, triple if it is a gigantic one.So. in order to improve the game:Get rid of vibrations, use eggboxes.Implement pulleys, everything was done with pulleys.Implement pendulums,I wanted to build a clock. Wait ! I know what you are going to say, I can build a pendulum, let me rephrase: Please make the ropes have an elasticity coef below 1, perpetual motion is not funny when it's occuring from bottom to top.Oh and belts &| chains would be nice, yes I am talking about the mechanical ones.Thankyou

content:
Posted: December 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								In Medieval Engineers, you can build whatever you want. A village? A castle? That part of Lord of the Rings? Yup. You can recreate all of those in this game with a wide selection of building blocks. There are also decorative blocks to make the inside parts feel less empty.Once you've built something, the second part of the game comes into play : Destroying it! You can build catapults and trebuchets to obliterate all of it in spectacular fashion.What I like a lot about this game is the constant updates every Tuesday, that add various things and fix annoying bugs.The Steam Workshop is also a great part of this game. You can see what others have created, such as castles or even floating islands.Performance wise? I get around 60 frames per second on max graphics on a GTX 1070, which is very satisfying.In a nutshell, I would totally recommend this game.And shameless self plug : if you were wondering what they added in the relaunch update :

								Well, it's launch day and that means everyone who's been drooling over this game is rushing to buy it.  Myself included.  That said, there might be a few people out there with questions.  Hopefully this will answer them.Medieval Engineers is an absolutely beautiful game.  Everything from the folliage to the map-edge backdrop is very well done.  The music is perfect, and brings you a true sense of that medieval feeling.  In addition the physics engine is the best I've seen in a building game.  This game is well worth the money.  That said, there are a few drawbacks to the current version of the game so I'm going to let you know what you'll be getting into.  Note:  This list ONLY applies to the EARLY ACCESS LAUNCH.  I have no doubt things will be updated in the coming days and months.  So here we go;- No Survival Mode.- No Multiplayer.- Map size is limited, although "Normal" is a pretty decent size.- Very limited selection of parts.- Building collapses can cause heavy lag.- Heavy load times on map entry.- Limited rotation of some parts.- During building it feels too much like "Space Engineers", lacking it's own identity.So, do I recommend this game?  HELL YES!  That said, if you're on the fence about purchasing it I'd watch the updates for now.  Wait until more parts are added and survival mode + multiplayer is included.  That way you won't be disapointed with your purchase.Otherwise, if you can deal with the limited state of the current game and trust solely in the knowledge that it will be improved, BUY IT NOW!

In the game, you play an engineer with the task of building a new castle for your feudal overlord.After many plot twists and backstabs in this political scenario that makes Crusader Kings 2 look like Sesame Street, you must hide the last remaining Engineers in an abandoned mineshaft whereupon an elevator is required. 								Hmm, I gave it a thumbs up, because it has potential..Early access so it's rough...beyond rough...Things that need attention:STOP with the Farking PvP mechanics! - my god it's listed as survival game..you are making the mistake of all survival games instead of getting people to work together you are driving wedges into the server communities..Character controller - the Unity character controller you chose is god-awful...Can't climb, can't jump over single block terrain..get's stuck in crevice terrain...third person camera wobbly(rocks back and forth when moving it)Survivabilty - No water!! seriously a person can live 3 weeks without food but only 72 hours without water. Food...eating 50 items every hour from foraging/farming just to keep food bar up...Some good points to consider:Voxel/marching cubes terrain is very nice...even 60+Fps on Highest settings using Nvidia GTX 1070. Very good view distance.Has potential to be AAA game in a few years.Building structures has pretty good mechanics...although not very intuitive...takes some getting used to...like any game with build mechanics..I liked how you can move the blocks in horizontal direction(need look at turning for vertical and diagonals)ALL in ALL, it DOES have potential....In 3 maybe 4 years of serious coding....Recommendation, wait for sale or more content.

content:
Posted: February 16
Early Access Review
								While this game is still heavily under development, it is already reaching unique heights. I mostly played online servers as there is so much more incentive when playing together. To be honest, it was a bit hard to find larger populations online, and i sincerely hope the game succeeds in providing a performance boost, and deeper pve/pvp/survival experience over time to improve on this.This game made me laugh and cry. I made a dozen of new steam friends all over europe, and for a while we really had some nice thing going on. It made me real life friends worry about my state of mind. I have clocked 700 hours in this game, and i have to lay it down for a while caus it started threatening my sanity. i'll be back, i'm sure.That being  said, this game is not for everyone at this point. It is not a casual game . The game demands high tolerance, struggling through the typical pain of early acces distortions.. occasional breaking of content, server wipe, annoying bugs, low player counts, a somewhat steep learning curve... demanding performance..  and a lot of time.underneath, there is a golden experience. If you like solving problems with wood, building and breaking stuff, digging tunnels through mountains, with a fair amount of roleplaying and making your own story, admiring creations of other people , gathering together to set up farms , elevators, balistas, counterweight devices, kung fu killer machines, trade centers- if you like dropping stones on your virtual friends head, have some friendly sieging engagements, firing a dozen chained balls through the air, copying buildings and churches of medieval times... it is really there. You just need to find the people to play with. You can start over and over and it never has to be the same. The player community is generally very friendly and supportive. The game attracts people with patience and determination and griefing is generally frowned upon. The commitment of the development team can be felt in many ways. Problems which are properly reported are usually adressed immediatly. After important updates developers and team leader can be found roaming the online servers to get feedback. I give this development team full credit and surely don't agree with anyone stating after -20 played hours 'game has been abanded' or something like that. It is untrue. on 5 different occasions i reported issues on the ME forum, and they were all but one fixed within two weeks. i am amazed by this level of interaction.

Early Access Review
								Finally, a piece of user-friendly software puts historical recreation right into everyone's grasp! In addition to being a fun sandbox/world-builder, Medieval Engineers is an extremely powerful engine for re-creating history. Even in its early-release Alpha stage, it already offers so much. You can build a town that's only known now in ruins & stories, and then explore it -- house by house, room by room. Attack it, defend it, live in it for a while. Team up with modders to populate your site with whatever art & artefacts & design styles you want. Whatever you wish! The future of gaming is bright with this program.

Early Access Review
								While most people give this game a thumbs down for it's bugs and unfinished state i'd like to get the truth out there. Rather than write an extremely long winded review that most people will skip i'm going to make a pros/cons list, and then add a few comments at the end.Pros:Fun and Rewarding SurvivalGreat PhysicsGreat Weapon Design SystemA Claim and Faction SystemCreative Mode For if You Feel Like Just Building or Messing AroundUnique Resource Collection SystemDecent AI That Does a Variety of Things (Peasants, Deer, Barbarians, Oh My!)Relatively Stable MultiplayerConstantly Updating (Most of the time to fix bugs, sometimes to add features)Round WorldFast TravelFun Banner Design SystemMany Other ThingsCons:BuggyDifficult To Run (Mostly GPU Intensive But a Good CPU is Required)RAM Hog (Atleast it used to be, don't know now that I have my new rig)Voxel Editing is TrickyThe Large Updates are Very Spaced OutDevelopment is Slow Female Player Model Looks a Tad Off  Update : It Looks Better NowNo Mechanization, Though They Are Working On It (For Example The Ever So Advertised Windmill Doesn't Actually do Anything, Just Spins)A Few Other Things I Couldn't Think of Off the Top of My HeadSummary: It's a great game, with alot of features, and stuff to do. As long as you don't mind the heavy system requirments, slow development, and ocassional bug.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								When it works, there's clearly the kernel of a decent game in here. It's clearly received less attention than Space Engineers, but there's still definitely something interesting and unique here.The building system is very flexible (especially compared to Space Engineers), letting you actually create believeable structures rather than cubes with 2m thick walls. THe destruction system is also really, really nice - buildings seem to collapse realistically, and walls splinter and form rubble in a hugely satisfying way. Structural integrity is satisfyingly frustrating - if you don't pay attention, buildings can collapse under their own weight.All that said, it's still clearly an early access game. There's virtually no AI to speak of, and the netcode is comparable to Space Engineers (dodgy af). To be expected, I suppose, in a game with a physics system as elaborate as this, but still frustrating. There's also some very iffy performance issues - again, to be expected in early access, but getting 0.5fps in the middle of a field on a GTX 1070 is rather frustrating.Overall, not bad at all - even if you just download castles from the Workshop and lob weights at them with a trebuchet.

Early Access Review
								I've had plenty of fun with Space Engineers, and Medieval Engineers is basically that, but with actual physics and a Medieval theme (go figure).Given the massive progress of Space Engineers, and this game being made by the same developers with their own dedicated team (as in not taken from the SE team) working on it, I'd say it's definitely worth picking up right now if you're willing to wait.If you aren't, wait until the game gets multiplayer and survival mode. It will be more than worth the price of admission then.Also, just in case you didn't read the store page, don't go into this game expecting it to be medieval Minecraft. With the structural integrity system this game has, you can't build the sort of fantastical structures you could in Minecraft. Hell, you probably won't even be able to build a small house properly on your first try. Yes, you can disable it, but why would you do that?

number of helpful: 24 of 38 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Still slow as hell.  The situation is you start out as a peasant and get to build a castle and siege engines.  For reasons that will be explained later, I never got so far as building the more advanced items.  Lack of an in game tutorial is still an issue, although there is an online one if you dont mind streaming it.  To start, you have to gather the basic resources to make some simple tools and workstations.  The tools help you gather resources faster and to build your fort.  I recommend keeping it simple at first, just a box with a door.  You will need to research better wals and so you will need to craft a research station, which can be built at the workstation.  Hence the need for a tutorial.The first thing you will notice is you will begin to starve to death frequently, and you need metric♥♥♥♥♥♥tons of food to fill you up, Im talking like 20 pumpkins.  I suppose the crafted food would be better, but again, I never got that far.  I built a small fort only to find out that doors are some kind of mythical super tech that you have to research once you have metal mining up and going.  So again, I didnt get to it.  Now normally I would give a game more than a couple hours on a re-review, but honestly, the framerate was giving me a headache.  I'm talking 5-7 frames a second on a quad core processor with a fairly new video card.    Coupled with the fact you cant trurn the food 'feature' off made it mildly unpleasant to re-review this title.  It's not a bad game if you can overlook the warts.  Gameplay -Probably the most important tech to research is farming.  If for no other reason so you can make bread, A simple recipe that fills you up.  Only requires wheat which you can find growing wild.  I recommend waiting to start building your first castle until you find an iron deposit, preferably near a forest.  Its a bit of a pain to find iron as it is quite rare.  Making it a strategic resource.  It can be found by looking for large areas in the grass where the grass looks dead.  Its yellow and red instead of green.  It took me about an hour of running around to find a deposit.  Once you find a spot, dig down anywhere from 2-10 blocks and you will find an iron deposit.  You can tell because the stone will be rust colored instead of white.  Once you have a deposit, you need to site your castle.  You can of course put yoru castle on top of the iron deposit.  The deposit I found is in the side of a mountain so thats not the easiest thign to do, so I started the castle about halfway between the mine and the nearest forest.  If you have barbarians turned on you may want to rush developing better weapons.  Sword and crossbow come in handy, especiialy the crossbow if you have your defences set up so you can shoot the barbarrians attacking your gates.All in all, It is a good game, and I would recommend it if not for the serious lag issues.  I've heard all the excuses about it still being early access, but seriously, the game has been under development for at least a year and the issues keep getting worse not better.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								Keen Software House brings us yet another "Engineering" game. This time however not in space but sort of safely on the ground.Those who are familiar with Space Engineers will certainly enjoy this game, the controls feel very much the same and the building mechanics ave a lot in common. However, there are some very vital differences, I'll list them later on.Those who are new to the "Engeneering" saga of KSH may need to put in a little more effort to get the hang of the controls and building mechanics but with a bit of perserverence everyone get's the of this game.The game is still in pre alpha, this means that everything is subjected to change, and crashes are not always inevitable. The game runs smoothly tough and feels like a proper early acces title. KSH is known for updating Space Engineers weekly, the same will probably happen to Med. Engineers. The major building mechanic differences:1) You can choose to build objects "off the grid" wich means they are not snapping to the ground or other objects, this means you can build objects that are moveable by e.g. walking in to them or making moving contraptions.2) You can now build multiple pieces of wall and a like in 1 bulding square. Buildings get more compact that way, something that is still not available in Space Engineers.3) Large and small blocks can easily be build on or to eachother without uses of converters and the sorts.4) Properly breaking objects, walls and the like.5) Optional (but recommended) building integrety wich means you got to really plan your builds to make sure they don't break under they own weight.TL;DR:It's a great and promissing pre alpha game that will certainly warm your heart if you like building, planning, medieval styles and a great dev team that updates their games reguarly and listens to feedback.Now buy it already and get constructing!

content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								After 5 months of hard remake under developer, our hero Tim Toxopeus, ME became something amazing. (He even visits servers and searches how to further improve this game him self, which blew my mind!), while releasing patch with features/fixes every week! There is so much you can do, whether you are creative arty player or survival focused. In creative mode, you can fly and create amazing castles, houses and devices and even terraform terrain to your liking. Just check workshop even for these beatiful amazing creations (awesome community and mods) working clock for example).  In Survival mode, you gather resources to build your structures and have to consider Structural integrity feature (too high walls may crumble), find and cook different food, create blueprints to learn, making mechanical traps against barbarians and much more. In multiplayer you claim territory for your House that you join, build clever castles on strategic positions, make traps and defences, and siege other houses using mechanical siege machines that you design your self. There is plenty of Role Play possibilities if you are into that too! Did I mention that you play on actual round PLANET? Beatiful environment with hidden ruins, treasures and caves, deers running around and day cycles with night. For this low price, Medieval Engineers are very good buy you WON'T be disapointed with. There are few bugs that most open world sandbox games have, but nothing immediately game breaking. Game is awesome as of now and it will only get even better after time with new features released every few weeks. Sandbox games are my favorites and ME is one of the best I've played. Now go and support our amazing active developers for all their hard work, to deliver you true medieval engineering!

number of helpful: 13 of 18 people (72%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								BASICALLY:Medieval Engineers is a wonderful game for anyone who is a big fan of middle age time period. It can appeal to almost any gamer, whether it being architecture (really cool structural integrity too), a survivalist (fun and immersive survival mode (more on that later)), and great potential on the PVP side of things. If you want to build medieval castles, villages, kingdoms even- this is the game for you. The game has both building and survival modes. Survival mode will immerse you into a role; build your kingdom, recruit friends, make enemies. Theres a couple issues with this, however.BIG CONS:1. EMPTY WORLDS   - Since its in EA, you could give them a pass. But currently, theres next to no animal life at all. This can make everything seem a little boring at some points of time, but half the fun of EA games are waiting for new exciting stuff to release :D2. NO MULTIPLAYER POPULATION   - While you can find one or two servers with active players, its not a lot. This isnt that big of a deal because singleplayer can be really fun, but multiplayer is good for roleplayers, PVPers, or if you tend to get lonely.  Find a multiplayer server if you can.3. BUGS   - Do not buy this game expecting it to be bug free. This is probably one of the buggiest survival games I've played- but it is still playable, and almost every weekly patch comes with its own set of bug fixes.BIG PROS:1. GENRE   - This is one of the best medieval building/medieval survival games you could buy.2. ROLEPLAY   - Even if your not into roleplay, you will find it hard to not roleplay if your on a server. And thats good! :D3. ARCHITECTURE   - Really cool, somewhat realistic building. Theres structural integrity, which means you can't just build stone cubes and expect to live in it. This keeps buildings true to medieval architecture.OVER ALL 7/10:   - Bugs are really bad in this game, they can screw you over. If there were a normal amount of bugs, it would be an 8/10.   - Imense potential; Good ideas,  Good development team, etc.

number of helpful: 15 of 22 people (68%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Buying Early Access Games always leave me quite concerned. There are a lot of them that promise much and deliver very few, taking too long to finish or even being released without getting finished at all. But THAT'S NOT THE CASE with Medieval Engeneers.There has been only a few months since this game has been released in Alpha and it is ABSOLUTELY ♥♥♥♥ING AWESOME already!! Keen Software House (the Producers) also produce Space Engeneers and both games are very well built. They are constantly being updated, mostly in a weekly basis (with bug fixes in a daily basis), and problems are very rare.Here goes a short synopse of what you get from this, yet brute but already quite refined, Diamond: - You get to build amazing Medieval Structures of Stone, Wood and Iron from scratch. - You can terraform the land, raise mountains, dig deep mines and build whatever you like upon it.- Construction is made through a very cleaver system of Stackable Blocks, which sometimes can be overlaid in order to create even more awesome composite blocks.- Blocks are affected by real Phisics. Weight, Height and Impact affect the blocks and they even crumble when overloaded.- EVERYTHING IS DESTRUCTABLE! You can build large fortresses just to have a lot of fun destroying it later on. And destroying it isn't only realistic as hell, but it's also very very fun!!- You can already build a wide variety of buildings (from tiny poor villager houses to might Castles and Citadels), and every week more and more blocks are released into the game.- The game also provides easy access to even more blocks from Steam Workshop's independant developers.- You can build not only fixed buildings, but also complex mechanisms like Lifts, Porticulis, Draw Bridges, Catapults, Onagers, Trebuchets, Balistas, Windmills, etc. AND THEY ACTUALLY WORK!!!This game is Heaven for your Creativity and only the sky is the Limit.I recommend this game, I recommend the producers and I also recommend buyinf it even on Early Access. If you liked to play with Legos when you were younger, you are sure to love it as much as I do.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
Early Access Review
About a year ago I hard about this game. I won't lie, I got super excited about it. In fact I got so excited I binge played Banished and Stronghold. I didn't want to get it yet because it was pre-alpha (very few pre-alpha games are good. Empyrion Galactic Survival is a good game and is in pre-alpha) and it would be too buggy.In case you don't know about the game, ME is you and some friends in a giant pit surrounded by mountains with a forest smack dab in the center (at least on our map) and you have to bum rush for items like food and such. You build a castle and combat your others of the game and can build an army of peasent's to do your bidding. We never got far enough to see WHAT the peasents would do, however, as the game is now only in alpha and the many bugs left in the physics engine would kill the peasents. I want to say now: these guys are building from the ground up. They might be using unity or something, but I am still in awe at how complex this game actually is in it's early stages.On to what I don't like here. As I said there are many physics bugs, however not so severe that if you get stuck in a crick in a hole you get shot into the atmosphere (this happens in 7 Days To Die, another good pre-alpha game). No, instead if you have your peasents doing generic things, like gather wood and stone, and have them flop it into a pile somewhere things have a tendency to slide wherever they want. EVERYthing on the map is a hill. You cannot go anywhere in the basin and not be climbing or going down something, Whether that is a bug in map generation or something, no clue. Because the items move around the AI trips over everything, including their own feet (which is really freaking funny to see). Bjorg and Helga can be hauling wood and stone while Ingvarad is organising wood, but then Bjorg hits Invar with a stick, nothing is actually no-collided in the engine, and then Bjorg, Invar, Helga, You, Half your castle, AND probably some trees are up in the atmosphere. Then some raiders run by and steal your♥♥♥♥♥♥ did I mention that? Fun fact the raiders are no-collided but nothing else is. You can walk through them. WTF.Next to that there is no tutorial. The game has been out a year and all you get is an obnoxious block of text that never goes away that says "HIT F1 TO SEE SOME♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; and then you have SEVEN PAGES OF KEYSTROKES to go through to learn how to build a wall. A freaking wall. Yeah you start out with some walls, but you have to figure this♥♥♥♥♥♥out like they did way back in 903. Now that I think about it that it kind of ingenius.....This would be fixed if looking at stuff would say "Hit T to Pick Up" or "Hit C To Open Crafting Menu!" In fact, if they would fix the damn inventory system that would be cool. I like it; it actually reminds me of games like High Seas Trader (dos game from 1992/5) but jesus♥♥♥♥♥♥man, you could do better..... Look up an image of it and try to figure it out, because I am lost A F. Actually NVM I can't even find an image bigger than 100X64...... It's bad, lets just say that. On one half you have a drop down to select a source, on the other half you have your pockets, nearby wagons, wagon's you aren't even close to, other players / NPC peasants, the ground, an ALL page (???) and a cargo page. I have no clue what all or cargo are, but it didn't bring me anything. Also the menu's will decide to disappear and reappear at random. I know what you're thinking. "Yeah you walked away from a chest or something right?" No, that chest is still in the inventory available space and I am on the other side of the map, but my pockets are not there........ This is an easy fix so no big prob there, but the inventory system needs to be thrown out and redone, even with legos, I don't care how.Earlier I said the game was complex A F. This is no joke. You have to build your siege weapons by hand. You get to design how they balance, pull, push, counter balance, all of it. With the bugs in the physics engine you couldn't have a rotary balista without it helicoptering to space, but you could do it nonetheless. I never figured out crafting but I imagine that it is just as wierd. Even picking up basic resources is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ Cut down a tree! And again! And Again! AGAIN! Try picking it up! Leave inv and try again! No? Well walk out of the map chunk and back and try again. There ya go!All in all this is an awesome game and anyone who picks it up will not be disappointed. If you're like me you jump in and immediately you think of a first person version of Banished. While it definately needs to have a lot of bugs exterminated and annihilated, pick it up, fund the devs, have a go with some friends, and I garuntee you that you will be laughing your♥♥♥♥♥off at some point.

number of helpful: 19 of 30 people (63%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								I do not like the idea of writing negative reviews on games. However, I cannot recommend this title in its present state. This one has been out for some time, and it is still very poorly allocated. The memory allocation makes the game almost impossible to run. I have a GTX970 video card, and a 4690 Intel processor, as well as 8G of ram. The game is not running worth a darn on it. It continually freezes up (usually after every single block placement while building), and then crashes to desktop, saying that there is sufficient memory for all the tasks running. The only things running is the Steam ap and the game. When the problem is posted on the discussion page, the devs do not respond. The only response I have seen is the statement that the individual's computer is not powerful enough to play the game. And this for a fairly high-end rig. The construction inventory, to be fair, is fairly extensive. However, it lacks some fairly vital and basic items. For instance, you can place statues around the castle courtyard, but there are no doors of any kind. No drawbridges, nothing. So either you cannot leave the keep, or the enemies can just walk in. I can see this oversight for a short while, but for any length of time it is pretty game breaking.As a multiplayer game it has some serious potential down the road, provided the devs actually (eventually) respond to, and address the issues in-game. But that time has not yet arrived. And as long as they ignore these legitimate concerns from their customers, the game is still fairly unplayable. As a single-player game, which the store page insists that it is, there is nothing to do but to build the architecture. No serious NPC's exist or are slated to ever exist as far as I can tell. That is not all bad. As a castle-building simulator, it could be fun for some people, and I would eventually be willing to recommend it at that time, provided the problems are addressed.

								===EARLY ACCESS REVIEW===This review is from an EARLY ACCESS STATE and may not be valid in the future.I first purchased this game when it had just come out on Steam. It was wonderful at that point, had a lot of promise.Unfortunately, I couldn't run it very well on my dual-core with 4GB of RAM, and r9-270x.Fast forward to now - I run an i5, 12GB of RAM, and the same 270x, and the game runs massively worse.When I first ran this game at release, I ran it on max settings at ~45fps, now with my upgraded computer I'm lucky to pull off 20fps at LOWEST settings at the same resolution. number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								I haven't been playing this game for very long, but I definitely enjoy Medieval Engineers.I came to it via Space Engineers, so I often compare the two and follow the two together. I've followed the progress both for quite some time, and I don't understand why some people would call the folks developing the games "stupid". It's disrespectful and inaccurate.So, in an effort to balance out a few really bad, really not nice, reviews from some people whom I'm happy not to know, I'm submitting my own review.For the record, I know what "Early Access" means. I don't regret spending $20 bucks on the game. I'd do it again. It's relaxing. Well, until a tree falls on you.Could use improvement:The help / controls seem to be incomplete or inaccurate. For example, I couldn't find anywhere that holding F will pick up some objects. I knew it could be done; I just didn't see find a button to do it in the controls setup. I didn't hear anyone mention it in any videos either, though I didn't watch many of them.Barbarians are ninjas: silent one hit killers. They stink.The odd dancing/wobbling thing your character does when trying to walk over stuff. Hey, I get it. Physics. Maybe the camera could be smoothed out? The same thing is in Space Engineers. I feel like I'm doing a little dance while trying to get out of holes! Ole! Going into 3rd person camera helps.I know it's selfish, but I rely on "community" content a lot in games. I see the community stuff for this game out there, but it's not to the level that I was expecting. A specific example is just trying to see how to make the furnace work. How many sticks to I have to burn for something, etc. I guess it's easier to find out info for Space Engineers than Medieval Engineers. I realize one is older than the other.Real nice stuff:Building. Yes. You can build lots of real nice stuff.If you don't enjoy building, then this isn't the game for you.If you don't like putting things together with your imagination, then this game is not for you.If you must follow some other person's plot and story to enjoy your time, then this game is not the game for you.If you want a finished product, then this game is not the game for you!Some people have compared this game to Minecraft. I don't see the comparison. This game actually has the concept of physics. Or something. Let's just say things fall, and roll. There's a crafting table. I guess that's how people are making the Minecraft connection. Whatever.I see people complaining about various features that are in the game and features and aren't in the game. I guess they can't see the big picture. Maybe the devs would do good if they release some kind of feature roadmap. Maybe they have, and I haven't found it.It's a building game. You build. In fact, the devs are still building the game. They send out updates very frequently. I don't get the feeling this is another one of those dead projects that I shelled out money for and got burned, because it was abandoned. Everything says otherwise.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								The thing to remember about this game is that it is early access. And oh, how early access it truly is.In its current form (I write this in April 2015, just after the addition of deer AI), I would not reccomend getting this game. At all. There are just so many bugs, lag issues and imperfections. I have faith they will be fixed as the game development progresses, but right now, it's horrific. And one thing stands out above all else.The game lags, all the time. Every time anything is hit by a projectile, or otherwise damaged by other means, the game freezes. And I don't want to hear any crap from people saying it's about system requirements; I have every single aspect of the reccomended PC specifications fulfilled, and it still behaves this way. You would have to hack into the Pentagon and use their supercomputers to run this game for it to be smooth, and even then it'd probably freeze every now and then.Oh, and the loading times. Good lord. It can take up to 3 minutes to load a level. Again, i'm sure this will be abbreviated by various adjustments to the physics engine and whatnot, but good god. Lord have mercy on the person who tries to open the replica of AC2's Monteriggioni someone made.I feel this game has tremendous potential, and will mature into a good, entertaining experience given time, but in its current form, I do not reccomend you pay £15 to play the lagfest that is April 2015's Medieval Engineers.

content:
Posted: April 25
Early Access Review
								Medieval engineers is the second game in the engineers series by Keen Software House, after Space Engineers.This review will touch on several topics concerning this game.Table of contents:1. Developers2. Gameplay3. Look and feel4. Content5. Stability and bugs6. Conclusion (TL;DR version)1. DevelopersI think it's very important to address this first, since at the time of writing there's some serious accusations being thrown about. This game is NOT abandoned. The company, keen, consistently updates this game weekly, and since a total work ethic change a few months ago, became one of the most consistent, structured ones i've seen.Updates are weekly on a tuesday, alternating between content updates, like new things to build, and bugfixing/stabilizing/optimizing updates. Once every few months, a major update is released, like planet-sized maps or farming/ores. i can't say i've ever seem them miss an update by a lot, unless they had a very good reason for it.2. GameplayMedieval Engineers plays like a mix between a survival and sandbox game. While the survival part has been traditionally rather barebones, improving on this has been the team's focus for quite some time now. Farming and tech progression are just some of the things the team has added to make this a richer experience over the course of the last year.As for the sandbox part - Medieval engineers isn't story-bound and allows the player to create whatever they want - there's also a creative mode to omit the survival aspect entirely for those who purely want to focus on building magnificent structures from the get-go. Despite the presence of creative mode, survival isn't compromised, and everything you can build in creative can be built in survival.3. Look and feelMedieval engineers, just like space engineers, takes a mostly realisti approach in it's visual style. the game is quite detailed but as a result does put a bit more 4. ContentAt this point, medieval engineers has a pretty decent ammount of content. there are still things both major and minor that are desired to be added, but there's definetely enough for a base game. While vanilla itself already allows one to richly decorate buildings from the inside and outside, both in terms of furniture and architectural variation, the modding community definetely helps by adding things that are too specific in taste for the game to automatically have for everyone. That is of course, not to say the mods fill the holes that the game leaves unfilled, it just adds those niche things that are more of an expansion than part of what would make the game whole.5. Stability and bugsI am aware that this section can be rather personal, and that's exactly why i beg your consideration when taking this in account while rating the game. the thing about bugs is that they're not always consistent. I personally haven't encountered any bugs that made me frustrated while playing. (honestly, i can't say i've encountered one recently at all), but i know that other players have. However, it's safe to say that at the moment there's no game-breaking bugs that are widespread across larger part of the community, or if there are, they are usually fixed in one or two updates. the dev team has dedicated every odd update entirely to fixing bugs and stabilizing and optimizing the game.6. Conclusion (TL;DR version)In my experience, medieval engineers is on the right track. It still has a way to go to reach it's full potential, but is definetely showing both promise and the will to move forwards. the game is pretty solid at this point, and it doesn't seem like the dev team is stopping anytime soon, with terraforming being the next major update set to release soon. While it definetely made a very slow start, it's picked up speed since 2015. i have to admit that i entirely quit playing somewhere in 2015 because the game was progressing so slowly, but when i came back to it a couple of months ago, i saw that it had grown into something far greater than what it was then. i think that given time, this can be a really solid game, and it's already pretty neat to play.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								In my opinion this game is pretty amazing as it is. The game engine itself is built by keen software, which is a lot more than most indie companies even try to do. The engine itself is what takes the most time in almost any game’s development process. The only other indie company I know of that makes its own engine is tale worlds.  Look at games like Ark Survivor Evolved which rake in huge profits and then demand more money for additional content before the game is even finished and it’s ran off of an already built engine for game designing. This game is still being updated and produced without requests for additional funds and the content is great. Yeah, it takes time for them to make the updates but if you knew anything about game design you’d realize that content in a game this detailed is time and labor extensive. I’m an aspiring game designer myself so I’ve learned to appreciate just how much work goes into these games and the fact that this game has one of the best physics engines I’ve seen for a game and some of the nicest graphics for an indie game based on its own engine I’ve nothing to complain about. Yeah, it has bugs but so does every early access game in existence because guess what we’re paying to alpha test the game! It’s not like it’s a finished product slapped with a full price tag and told that it will work 100%. Triple A titles do this to us all the time and when it has bugs they patch them after release and you’ve already dropped 60-80 bucks on it! Just look at Rome 2 total war, Battlefield 4 and almost any other triple A company’s games when they come out fresh from the cooker. Keen, I don’t know if you read these but if you do thank you so much for being an honest and amazing company, Keep up this amazing work and I’ll continue to recommend this game along with space engineers  to everyone I know because it is a rare thing to see a company which has some real honor behind them.

Early Access Review
								     I have been playing this game since its release and I have really enjoyed the creative element of it.  I understand it is in "Early Alpha" therefore it still has its issues.  I have Space Engineers also and seeing how well that game has grown an advanced I would only expect this game to do also.  The level of game detail is great, the depth you have when building and creating machines is amazing.     If you enjoy Space Engineers / Minecraft style creative games then this is for you.  I think this game is just going to get bigger and better and may I dare to say might rival Minecraft if they push it in that direction.  Anyone sitting on the fence about this game should jump off and get it quick.     There are current system requirements to play the game that are quite high so please be sure to check it will run on your machine before you buy.  Also this is a "Early Alpha" game so be aware it has very minimal content other the creative mode but what is there is a lot to work with already.     So in closing I highly recommend this game, but do your homework about it before you make your final decision.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								TL;DR at the bottom.Lets just start with this: The reason I haven't written this review yet was because I couldn't take my face out of the game itself.ALSO This game is early access (and I mean "it got released today" early) and if you do not know what that means, it means that it is in early development and will grow in the future.Aside from one sentence remarks, let's start with a basic summary. Most people probably know that Medieval Engineers is Keen Software House's second "Engineers" game (for those who don't know, Space Engineers is the first and I thought it was spectacular). This game has a whole new level of interesting and unique features, and both Space Engineers and Medieval Engineers are going to feed each other ideas. For example, ME had  "Voxel hands" first, then SE got them. So, back to this game and ONLY this game. This game has smooth gameplay, solid building, few bugs that I can see, and is very beautiful graphics wise. Two of the main features you come across very early in gameplay are the destruction physics and compound building. 1. Destruction physics: The detsruction of buildings reminds me a lot of "Red Faction: Guerilla" and it's GeoMod engine. When a catapult projectile is dropped on a building, it will crack and shoot dust up. When a catapult projectile is charged up and launched, it does major damage. When a full building block (or a whole building itself) is dropped on a building, it is just turned to rubble. The destruction is solid and satisfying to cause.2. Compound building: This is a feature I hope gets implimented into SE. I am positive it will. Here's what it does: Let's say the whole in-game building system is on a grid of 1x1x1 cubes (let's call it a unit). So 1 block of stone is a whole unit, 1 stairs block is 1 unit and so on. Well, If you have walls that are placed to the edge of the unit, then you could not place 2 walls to make a corner in a 1 block unit. With compund building, you can. So you can do it with almost any block.Now, PROS and CONS:Pros:1. Gameplay: Solid, smooth and fun. Pretty straight forward. 10/102. Graphics: The worlds are beautiful and very scenic. Even the buildings themselves and the medieval textures are very realistic and quite spot on. There is 1 bug where placing multiple blocks in 1 slot makes textures glitch in the spot that the material overlaps. But not too big of a deal. 9.8/103. Building: The building is solid and fun. Easy to do, but takes some getting used to. 9.8/104. Controls: There are alot of controls to learn and shortcuts to master, but it is not too hard to get a grip on. 9.5/105. Complexity/simplicity balance: One thing I look at in any building/crafting game is how simple it can be for simple people, while also being ABLE to be very complex for very creative people if they so choose. This game does it. You can simply build houses, or use medieval machinery to build crazy contraptions quickly and actually quite easliy, and of course there will updates and optimizations. 10/10Cons1. *YOU CAN IGNORE THIS ONE FOR NOW; VERY EARLY ACCESS GAME* Not very much content, so if that is what you are looking for, you should wait a few weeks, months maybe.2. Map size: As far as I can tell, the maps are not very large, and are not procedurally generated. HOWEVER this might (and probably will) change in the future. TL;DRVery good game with solid gameplay, beautiful graphics, a lot of controls but easy to use, and smooth overall. Not many cons other than the map size. Very early access so there isn't much content yet, however, I recommend this game for sure.I hope this review helped you make a decision. :)

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Short review-amazing.  Well worth 20 bucks if you enjoy building castles.Long Review-ProsHard game to stop playing.  There is always one more build to attempt and one more looky-loo at your creation.  After spending 3-4 hours messing around, learing the controls, I have been putting together an imense mountain castle that includes a drawbridge, portculi, dozens of towers, houses, and catapults.  It is easy to get lost in your work while hours pass by.  The graphics are beautiful, and on my new Alienware, I see the grass and trees sway in the breeze.  I get the same feeling playing this game that I got as a kid playing with legos nonstop, oblivious to the world.But, there are a few problems that can be frustrating.It's Alpha.  There is clunkiness to the controls, especially in clearing debris.  As others have mentioned, the buildings you constuct need to be over-engineered or they will tumble down.  There is a lack of variety of materials to flesh out your castle: a bed, table, dresser, and a chair is all you get for now.  Roofs can be very anoying to place correctly and if you misplace, you often delete the walls underneath in addition to the section of roof.   You also have only a half a dozen maps to choose from, none of which are overly large.  There is no water as of yet, so no moats.  Smoothing terrain is perhaps the most frustrating part of the game for me so far.  Instead of pushing down on terrain, you add up.  The controls are clunky, awkward, and no way to take away or delete terrain.  No food, crops, animals, resources, blacksmithing, or fine crafting of any type.  Flying can test your nerves as well.  Gravity doesn't exist if flying mode, so inertia sends you at mach 1 with just a touch of the controls.  You often need to be in the perfect spot to place a block, and the inertia controls require fine little pushes in the direction you want to travel in.  Plus, you are invulnerable and if you send yourself flying into a wall, if often comes tumbling down as cuss words tumble out of your mouth.You can't name saved games, which can be anoying and load times can be long.  Finally, my last gripe is copying and pasting.  Currently, you copy everything already created.  So, let's say your castle is rocking, but you want to add some catapults.  You are forced to save, restart a new game, create your catapult, copy, exit game, and finally go back to your saved castle to plop and paste the weapons.  But, and I can't stress this enough, the game is very adicting.  For an Alpha, it's more than playable and it should only get better with more features being brought in.  Multiplayer could be a blast, as long as they toughen up the integrity of your creations or battles could be very very quick.  Overall, two fat thumbs up!

content:

Early Access Review
								After playing quite a bit of Space Engineers i was thrilled when the developers announced they would be making a Medieval Engineers. I preordered space engineers when it was in alpha(taking that risk of whether or not it will be worth it down the road) and after watching it grow and evolve was amazing. I have no doubt in my mind this game wont succeed if the devs put the same amount of work and effort into both listening to the fanbase and keeping new content flowing as they did with Space Engineers.Now they are missing alot at the moment from resource gathering to even rope tention so my monstrousity of a trebuche can't actually fire the ball. None the less i have no doubt that both of these along with multiplayer will be coming soon due to my past experience with these devs. Never had any issues with major bugs in their games and they've earned my trust for sure.So im very excited to see more content be released to build onto what theyve already started. From the amazing and im sure painfully to cod rock deteriation/destruction to the well built physics engines within the game i fully reccommend this game. Its in alpha but it has alot of potential and i believe the Dev team will have no trouble turning the game into something worth more then 20$
