content:
Posted: February 27
Early Access Review
								Hello Nerds and Nerdettes, I have spend some time researching this game and here are my conclussions. Below there is everything yu need to know in a writen format but here is a video in case you prefer to spend 5 min watching instead of reading 


YouTube™ Video: Early Access Monitor - Is Medieval Engineers worth it? - Early Access Review 

			Views: 1,113		

			Welcome to Early Access Monitor series. Today we are going to find out Why Is Medieval Engineers Getting more Negative Reviews On Steam.		

Game has been out for just over 2 years with first public build coming out on 19 of February 2015. And until now around 270,000 people bought the game with majority of the purchases happening in initial months. Currently there is about 7750 active players of the game and that number had risen from 4000 in September so we are seeing a bit of positive trend over last few months. Last but not least the game review scored has dropped dramatically from it’s original reception. As always it is essential that people who buy early access understand that they buying an experience rather than fully developed product. It is implied that product will improve over the years but you must understand that the product may evolve in a ways you may dislike. Okay with all the facts and this little introduction  in mind let’s look at a potential reasons in review drop and what that means to you potential customer. First the description of a game reads as: Medieval Engineers is a sandbox game about engineering, construction and the maintenance of architectural works and mechanical equipment using medieval technology. Players build castles; construct mechanical devices and underground mining. There is an entire planet to explore!What a time to be alive! I have always been impressed by the technological miracles engineers achieved with simple technology like rotors, ropes and powers of nature. We can easily imagine that people who bought into the product are modded minecraft veterans, Nerds and Nerdettes that enjoy tweaking their build, constructing impossible machines with clever use of simple technology. Modern day wannabe engineers who like a challenge that medieval times bring. Here however lies the problem with the game. For first year and a bit game lacked a lot of direction developers were jumping from one update to the other with what felt like absolute lack of road map. Game started to drift away from it’s original purpose of engineering and machine building and more towards building design and multiplayer. After a while they started adding survival element. Of course survival elements and multiplayer are essential to keep game like this alive and challenging but slowly very focused goal of making engineering game shifted into making more general survival experience. This left many people disappointed as it wasn’t initial promise of the game. I think this lack of direction was a major factor in increasing disappointment and slow death of playerbase. Medieval Engineer subreddit has stagnated in subscriptions as you can see in here: http://redditmetrics.com/r/MedievalEngineers and now look at what happen in other early access games with more focused development like Software Inc http://redditmetrics.com/r/SoftwareInc for example or Kerbal Space Program http://redditmetrics.com/r/KerbalSpaceProgram back when game was in early access or even Space Engineers http://redditmetrics.com/r/spaceengineers older sister game of Medieval Engineers. As you can see game struggles to attract new fansI think major contributor to the state of a game is that team set themselves for a failure with weekly update schedule. Sometimes in game development you just have sit down and fix bunch of bugs, or code a major piece of work that will take small team few weeks to do. When you are pressured to release something new every week you end up focusing on minor additions rather than major patches. Even one of most recent updates is a door noise improvement. Is it nice that they tweaked it to be more natural? Sure. Is it important at this stage of development? Not so much. Okay let’s now focus on positives since October time when Planet updates was released development feels much more focused and it gives out the impression that someone took a dev team together sat them down and decided on a game vision and has more consistent plan in achieving it. Still weekly updates disturb the flow hence door noise update etc. but it’s much better that it was prior to that. With the new focus we have seen increase in active players bringing back some of the old veterans of the game. I am hoping that this focused direction will be consistent and will reignite the spark in the community and brings back more players, modders and content creators. From my brief chat with veterans of the game people who endured creation process of last 2 years it feel s it has been worthwhile experience and they feel game progressed Okay so what is Medieval engineers really. It is Medieval survival game with focus on multiplayer and base building with some focus on machine building. If you want the game in a spirit of Life is Feudal you will have fun with Medieval Engineers. If you want a game about building new machines and engineering it gives you some aspects of it but not enough to buy on the merit of this alone. Overall Medieval Engineers development is better than some of Early Access projects I have seen but game evolved a lot from it’s original form. Approach with caution or simply wait another year. As always with Early Access don’t buy the game on hopes on potential but it only if you like it in current format. Nerds and Nerdettes my name is Feniks and I hope you had a great time watching today's Early Access Monitor and you are able to make better informed decision about the game. I am looking forward to your opinions in the comment section down below and hope for some good discussion. Have a nice day.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have played a couple of hours of the game, BUT! The game right now is small, so I can allready take a solid review.When I firstly launched the world, I felt like I have just appeared in the Medieval Era. The nicest medieval music and nice grassy plain met me with happiness and temptation. Then, turning left 135 degrees, I saw a house. I walked to it and sat inside, feeling really cozy. Although, then I saw big projectile in my belt. Of course, it is really obvious what to do. I saw how to control those in a really friendly presented tutorial. So, I walked out from that cozy 15th century house and picked up my projectile and BOOOM. The house is to the ground. Great havoc-ish damage physics - KSH always deals with those damage physics, in all their recent games.     Okay, I wanted to build a castle like this Neuschwanstein one. I found a mountain, terraformed a bit of ground for the keep and started building. I made a nice guard tower, which fromed so SOFTLY and INTUITIVE, which I can't say for some games, even, sometimes, Space Engineers. I copied the tower, although, it took me a big bite of my time to mess around with copying and pasting it. I couldn't rotate it. Although, I am going to close my eyes on ot - it's a magnificent alpha.So, I saw another problem - maybe I am doing something wrong, or don't know how to do it. But I built my towers sideways to the "voxel grid". I would need to build my walls the wacked way. *Sadface:(*So, let's see, what is positive, and negative about this game.+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++1. Nice, Fluid and intuitive building system.2. Nice graphics. Not the best, but they are good for the game of this type.3. MAGNIFICENT damage physics, and structual integrity.4. Mechanical elements. And weapons, that you build yourself, which means, that if you are in multiplayer, better you build your Trebushetes ( or smth. ), the better you will siege.-----------------------------------------------------------------1. Sometimes crashes. You can drop this off, because it's an early acces game.2. Hard terradorming. You need to get your hands dirty and whack for a little bit, before building.3. Sometimes, whacky movement/dissy camera. Well, that is the problem of all the games from KSH.Just deal with it.Although, I give this game a good 8,5/10. It's a great game with big potential.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								Its minecraft for adults. Sort of. It plays alot like space engineers, which is a good thing, but it it has the creative factor that minecraft used to have. Its incomplete, its got some bugs, especially in block rotation and placement. You also cant delete debris yet, but there are ways around this. And structural integrity is a great feature, If you build like you might, in say minecraft or even space engineers, the game will punish you. you have to think ahead, what's going to need support, will x block be strong enough, etc. Its like playing with your cat, one moment everything is great, all is well, but then you do just the wrong thing and your getting bitten or clawed. but you don't mind, you keep on playing, because just like your cat, Medieval Engineers is just too lovable to stop playing, even if it does leave you cut and bleeding.As far as debris is concerned there are two ways of dealing with it. One is to wait for them to delete themselves after a few minutes, but this wont get rid of blocks still intact enough to count are a full block but have come loose. Alternatly you can start a game, then save and go back to the main menu, go to load the save, but instead of loading your save go to edit settings and set the debris limit to 0. Blocks will still break and loose blocks will still fall, and poorly built structures will still colapse. But, there will be no anoying little debris that you can't delete with a right click. Beyond that, everything else is straight forward.Buy it now while its on beta discount, you wont regret it.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
Early Access Review
RedemptionWith the release of 0.3.1 (October 18th) I feel that I must change my review as the dev team from KSH has redeemed themselves a lot with this most recent release. They have not only introduced a world, with fast travel capabilities, but they have finally fixed many annoying issues from the past. (targeting issues, motion sickness / FOV issues, etc) Is the game perfect? Not yet. Is the game completely free of bugs or issues? I don't know, it's still a game in early access so I'm sure there will be glitches and bugs along the way. But the game breaking issues seem to be resolved at this point and the dev team appears to be back on track. Let's hope the trend continues! I still have high hopes for this title. At this time I'm going to give this a thumbs up, for now! Good job!

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Medieval Engineers is in its early stages as I write this review.Have you ever played block building games and felt the need to place foundations and build buttress, even though the game physics don't require it? Ever looked at a floating building with despair?Then THIS is the game for you. Composite building and structural integrity mean you can build a realistic building where the design matters far more than in any other game of this kind.I have clocked quite a few hours on this so far, and I can see myself whiling away a good chunk of my spare time here. I love the way you can build structures from deep basements to towering watchtowers that will collapse if I do it wrong!Don't get me wrong, the physics aren't too punishing. You won't have your buildings falling apart every five minutes. It's just a relief to build structural supports where they actually have an effect.The potential of this game has only just begun to be realized. I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys building. Also, to anyone who loves to destroy and test the strength of a tower.[Addition] After a couple of months, I do find a degree of frustration with this game. Lag and frame drop are a very real issue everytime you know down a building. As I see much of the fun of this game in the destruction of what I build, this has become a real disappointment. I also love the idea of playing multiplayer, and running through a building my friend is destroying. Again though, lag is intense when destroying things, making this an almost unplayable feature.It is my hope that this game will improve, but it might be worth waiting a while.

Early Access Review
								There has not been a substantial update in forever.  It feels like this game is in developement limbo, and with the lack of direction or anything that seems like an intended goal, I can't recommend this game.  It seemed very promising and fun at first, but given the fact that I bought it based off the potential of it---and how well they were doing with Space Engineers... I feel very burned by this game.  It seems like their "Update Tuesdays" are a joke compared to the leaps Space Engineers used to take.  Want the same boring blocks over and over again?  How about in three colors!  Wood, stone, and white?  This game is for you!  Want awesome destructability, but to feel limited by the plain and bland looking materials you are given?  Then definately buy it!  Want to be frustrated when every "update" they have is some BS mechanic that's just a re-tooling of what they've already done in the first place?  By all means pick it up.Otherwise, don't waste your time.  Hopefully that will get them to put some drive and be more ambitious with this game... because right now it feels abandoned.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								Very cool building sandbox, with some very amazing features. -Currently has a few problems. -However these can be overlooked by simply saying that it just came out and is in alpha 1. -Terraforming is one of the craziest systems I've ever seen in video games -The voxal system is very creative and you can create caves with it too, no 90 degree slope limitations and such. -Many ground textures to use. -Building allows you to place objects inside eachother and has virtually no drawbacks other than a slightly confusing learning curve.-Structural integrity system that you can analyze [N reveals a graphical display debug for structura integrity]-Many blocks have veriants to choose from to allow more creative ability [Scroll Wheel will reveal veriations in things like roof blocks]-On another note, this game also has the abillity for mechanics and machines to be incorperated into you're structures.-Graphics are above par --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Overall worth you're $21.99 [CND] if you like sandbox, and creative building games.Additional Information: The game likes to crash on me a lot, so I have to save when doing anything that involes lots of work, looking into updating graphics drivers, planning to recheck after.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Keen Software House has come crashing down to Earth, it seems. Hot off the heels of their success with Space Engineers, the studio has taken a decidedly different approach to its next game. Yes, they’ve swapped the dark, lonely nothingness of outer space for the green and pleasant fields on Terra Firma. And whilst the core gameplay of Medieval Engineers is, in essence, no different from Space Engineers – build stuff, destroy stuff – it goes that extra mile to engross you in its twee setting. Medieval Engineers, like Space Engineers before it, launched as an Early Access title with a solid amount of content, and whilst its current incarnation only lets you build stuff just to knock it down, it gives an exciting glimpse at the possible shape the game might take in the future.Before you can indulge in senseless destruction you’ve got to build something first and, even at this early stage, the creation tools on offer are surprisingly slick. You can choose from a different number of fields to start out in, be it a rocky hill terrain, or a plain with a castle town already in it. Building your own castles using the various building blocks available to you is a cinch, and the auto-snap grid means that you will line everything up correctly – almost every time! I say “almost” because, at present it can be a real pain the undersatchel to line up floor panels. That’s before I have even touched on the terraforming tools.So, you’ve started building that ridiculously oversized mountain fortress and want to even out the ground a little, well it isn’t  going to be that easy. Terraforming, in theory, should be easy: you pick your brush shape, give it a width, height and depth, and can set about adding or subtracting ground blocks to the scene. There’s a bit of an art to it though, meaning you need a steady hand to keep things smooth – otherwise you end up with ground that has the texture of artex. Indeed, my inability to use the tool effectively saw me creating underground caverns that had an eerily beautiful quality to them, but I couldn’t get out! Hopefully, future releases will see these tools tweaked a bit for people like myself (idiots, basically).You needn’t build alone, either! Get a buddy or two in on the action and you’ll be up and running with a serviceable castle in no time; the system really is just that astonishingly easy to use. Think of it like minecraft where each block looks different and has different properties – except they aren’t cubes, of course. There are all sorts of different blocks at your disposal, from round-edged  walls for turrets, battlement attachments, and windmill blades for the show-offs.Humans will be human and it’s in our nature to tear down and destroy, and Medieval Engineers has you well covered in that department. Technical dunces like myself can equip small and large cannonballs to their hotbar and let rip a volley of shots on their structures, watching them crumble to the ground in a cloud of smoke and dust. There’s a perverse pleasure to be had in seeing your time-consuming efforts reduced to nought but rubble within a few minutes,  a feeling which is amplified by the warming celtic soundtrack that plays throughout. It’s a highly incongruous matchup, but also very enjoyable. You can further amplify the destruction by kicking your map’s maximum fracture pieces all the way to the top – your PC won’t thank you for it, but it sure as hell looks amazing! If you have the technical cojones to create catapults, trebuchets and other machines of war you can also set your mind free to think up the most dastardly creations it can. When you are done you can upload them to the Steam Workshop for others to enjoy – a feature that will no doubt become inundated with cool items I only wish I had the skills to create.There is so much untapped potential waiting to come out of Medieval Engineers that it’s difficult to see what form the final game will take. Keen have recently released an update featuring barbarians so who knows, maybe we will see a full-on medieval war simulator, with massive castle-vs-castle battles? I’ll see you all there when I manage to get out of this damn hole!-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Disclosure: Preview key provided by Keen. Original review available at: http://criticalindiegamer.com/2015/02/medieval-engineers-preview-pc/

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Yes, I would recomment this game myself. You have to realize though:1) This is still an Early Access game. Some of the features you EXPECT in this game, may not be applied yet.2) It came out not too long ago. You have to give it time before you negatively affect the reviews. As of now, There isnt much to do, but master the games mechanics and learn how to build. You can destroy things, and as of yesterday i believe, You are able to spawn barbarians to do the destroying for you.I wouldn't recommend this game if it wasnt for one slight detail.The developers are active. They are informing the community and are searching for ways to improve the game. Great people, and i do not believe they would abandon a game that was already advanced into early access. Especially since they can see the potential. We all have seen games where the devs havent notified the community in months. No updates in a year or so, and all the updates they do are just average bug fixes. I can tell you from my time playing Space Engineers (SE) That this is not the case.Note: Please also take into account that they are still working forward in SE. They applied workshop for us to keep ourselves entertained so they can have time to get what they need done, done. It's not a fast process.I will keep updating this as time moves along, as of right now the question is simple:Do you want to be part of a growing, excited community and support the devs?*UPDATE* 3/10/2015Finally added some new things! They now added barbarians, a survival setting where barbarians will attack your king statue every certain amount of minutes! Im really excited about this update. however, there are still many glitches. Like turning into jesus after throwing a cannonball. Freeze Framing in midair. Along with, barbarians attacking eachother instead of the statue, Barbarians throwing cannon balls BACK AT YOU (kobe), and The whole building youre in collapsing from one hit. lol. The glitches so far are very amusing. That is why i still suggest this game. I will keep updates as the game goes on.*UPDATE*  3/25/2015They finally!! Added!!! Ragdolls!!! You now have a day and night cycle. Which makes the survival more a bit more interesting. Along with that you know have pick axes, and other hand tools such as the torch and mace for defense. I have yet to try the full experience for the survival mode, for ive been very busy, as soon as i do i will update again. I'm hoping they added material requirments in survival mode to build with. Either way this game keeps getting better and better. The developers are cracking down hard on this game. However the only MAJOR con that i can see in this game so far, (well besides the things they havent added yet) Is the ability to spawn bots. Yes, this is an early access game and they probably dont have the patches to support alot of bots walking around the world at this time but i feel if you want to crash your game? crash it. lol. Right now you are only able to spawn 4 to 5 barbarians and and 3 peasants. Peasants will stockpile your ammo crates. Where they stockpile them at though is not under your control at this time. Example:I buillt a Practical castle. 4 walls. Each corner had a rotating catauplt on it. Outside I build a couple houses for scenery. Inside the castle were:BarracksA main hallMess hallCourtyardStatueGardenand War room. along with an extra hidden passage out. (i havent yet mastered the art of digging underground so it was just a doorway hidden by bushes and trees. I was launching my catapults for fun, and decided to test out the peasants. I noticed he took the ammo off of my catapult head every time i spawned one before i could launch it. This took my interest. I followed this young fellow of which i named jerry. I followed him far and wide. Out of the reaches of my castle. Through the hidden passage. Far into the reaches of the forests. Passed the hills. The he stopped. only for a second. Dropped the rock. Turned around and ran back to the castle. -_- I stayed put trying to figure out why he dropped the rock there. I waited. He came back with another rock. Dropped it in the same place. To speed things up, i spawned in 2 more peasants. To which they continued to fight over where the rocks would be placed. one would pick it up. walk over five feet and drop it. to which the other would pick it up and run another five feet and drop it. This continued until the other one came back with YET ANOTHER rock.... At which time they killed eachother by picking it up (and i guess glitching) And causing two of them to ragdoll. Other than that, yes i recommend this game. The devs are hammering down to add new parts. In the end it will truly be an amazing game.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								New life has been breathed into this game! I played it a little bit before the new director (Tim) joined the team. Over the past 5 months there has been a hiatus on updates so the team could do a complete ground-up rewrite. The new version with planets and land claims adds much more focus to team play and pvp. Where before the game was a basic sandbox with no real goal, now Houses can make alliances or got to war. Areas can be claimed by players and shared with other players in their House.The game still has a long way to go. Many features have rough edges that need to be refined. There are some mechanical blocks that still need to be added to the game. The dev team does a great job of informing players of updates and changes in the weekly update videos every Tuesday. If anything goes wrong in an update you can be sure the dev team will roll out a hotfix to solve the issue.I've observed some very promising behaviour on the multiplayer servers. Complete strangers will play together and work to accomplish a goal, like building a watchtower to guard a village, or constructing a wall around their area. However, as with all sandbox games there is the problem of griefing. Players will join random servers just to wreck stuff and see things break. The developers have said they are looking at way to add offline protection. It is good to know they are aware of the problem and are already working on solutions.Unlike Space Engineers, another Keen Software House game, there is a suprising lack of "Clang" (weird physics bugs and breakages). You can build contraptions out of rope drums, catch blocks, and other mechanical blocks. Even on multiplayer servers it's no problem to have functioning siege engines rolling around the world and launching projectiles. There is sometimes a noticable drop in sim-speed, especially when a wall or tower is collapsing, but optimizations in future updates will alleviate that.If you enjoy multiplayer sandbox games I would highly recommend Medieval Engineers. Find a group of friendly players and make a House on an active server and you will have hours of fun ahead of you.

content:
Posted: February 6
Early Access Review
								Midieval Engineers is made by the same company as space engineers and in a lot of ways is strikingly similar. There are a number of differences though. The primary difference appart from setting, is the survival mechanics. While playing the survival mode of this game you do not start with the full knowledge of the different crafting materials or building materials. Instead you must research the different technology teirs to progress farther. In my opinion this mechanic is something that propells the game forward and prevents it from stagnating and resulting in a fatigueing issue that i so often have in space engineers.Another key difference is the introduction of structual integrity. This prevents you from building structures that have no means of supporting themselves. This makes the game feel not only more realistic, but also more flushed out as far as physics go.Pros--Fun sandbox experience-Lots of exploration-Regular updates and development schedule (Every Tuesday)-Stunning graphics and beautiful scenery-Many more building features than that of space engineers-Better keybinds than space engineersCons--Requires a decent ammount of power to run reliably-Still many bugs due to the alpha build status (NOTE: I do not hold anything against the title for the alpha build status and while i am aware that the number of issues in the game i currently have are directly related to the development cycle of the game and its alpha status, i do believe in reporting on anything and everything that would change or otherwise impact the experience of the player)-The UI is clunky and awkward to use-The UI is not very intuitive (Devs have stated UI changes are on the way)-Character controls feel stiff

content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								Long story short, wait until this game is fully released or at least into a beta before buying it. It was a fantastic game when it first came out but the amount of bugs it currently has will make you regret spending the money. I'll preface this by saying that I was super excited to get this game when it first became available. As soon as I could I was playing it and I was amazed how well it worked for an alpha. At first there were very minor issues and bugs but overall the game was very playable, it was just a little lacking in features.Then they started to pander to the people demanding a survival mode and multiplayer (before the underlying systems were fully there). The result? More bugs than you'd find in a hoarder's house.Now I keep having the game just display blinding white, blocks that refuse to fit together like they had before, and control issues. It seems every update they add just makes things worse. Hell, most updates seem to be them trying to make multiplayer function more than trying to get the base game working.Call me crazy but multiplayer needs to be dealt with after the basic functions are all there. Otherwise you have a completely unplayable game rather than just a limited one.The problems Keen had with Space Engineers got resolved and I have no worries that Medieval Engineers will end up working. At the moment though, they are trying to do too much so you need to wait until the game can be finished so save yourself the headaches of wanting to play the game, but quitting because of the bugs. I used to spend hours building cities and castles, now I avoid the game. I come back to it every once in a while but right now, it’s best to just not play it.The videos you see were how the game played on original release. Literally, what you see in the videos they show you was how the game looked and worked in April 2015. If you want to see how Medieval Engineers works now, open word, zoom in 250% and stare at the white screen. That’ll be the current medieval engineers status and playability. If you read this, buy the game, then leave a bad review because of bugs, just know satan has a very special place for your kind. Overall, buy this game when it is fully released.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								Development hasn't stopped for this game. Please consult the keen software house forums for varification. Also refer the the development diaries on the changelog for this game. As it stands now, if you are looking for a complete game, this isnt it. If you are looking for a survival game, this isn't it. If you are looking for something that requires engineering..this is it. Watch some videos, read more reviews, just please be cautious of negative reviews. Lot's of people are negative these days without doing proper research before purchasing. Don't be that man or woman. With early access, you get to buy an unfinished, unpolished game that has a good bit to offer. You get to see the deveopment of a budding game to it's end. If you like building and destroying castles or houses, this has a great destruction mechanic along with a nice structural integrity system. The game promises fast travel, enemy AI barbarians, Farming, water, more intutive mechanics, and a unique combination type building mechanic that allows for some very interesting construction techniques. I reccommend this game to any person who is patient and interested in crafting games. As it stands, you could probably have a good 30 hours of fun at the least just building and destroying things. Please for the love of all that is living, watch some gameplay before you make assumptions and buy. These devs have never showed anything that they do not plan on implementing. Right now the game is in a standstill for update releases. They are working on a full planet system with procedural generation. A larger task is ahead of them and I'm glad they are putting forth all of their effort in doing that instead of weekly updates. Do not expect a refund, do not expect or speculate on anything that isn't already in the game. There is nothing in the world that prevents a company from exiting early access before the customers think the game is done. As with all early access games, don't expect more and cry when there isn't. I give this game a 6/10 right now. It's fun, playable and has enough features to keep you entertained for a bit. If it had more, then I would give a higher rating.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								First of all, I love the whole idea. And since I've played Space Engineers, I decided to pick up this game and give it a try. The idea of being able to freely build and construct in medieval settings speaks to me, and I can imagine many others. There are just some issues that makes it unplayable. 1. Optimisation. I know that the game is in Alpha state, and developers prioritising content over optimizing it. My rig is quite strong, but I still have to play this on low settings due to the pure lag and sometimes freezing of the game when blocks start to crumble, or walls falling apart, not to mention it restrict you as a player to build small, stripping a lot from the game already.2. Content. Now, it has a lot of basic content for us to get starting and building, but it still aint fun when after an hour or so, you've basically gone trough it all. And as aforementioned, the poor optimization prevents from building any larger structures without having to sarcrifice something.All in all, a good game but I think it needs to mature a bit more as we say around here. It needs a lot of work before it can be proper played and immersed into, the only thing at the moment keeping it alive, would be the mods.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								How to play Medieval Engineers : 1: Buy Space Engineers instead.The game was interesting to say the least at first. Instead of starships and space stations, you make castles and catapults and such.   A refreshing change you could say,  but it quickly wore off.  And I mean quickly.The game is dead, has been since release. It never gets updated. The servers are too buggy to play on(if they even have any players)   KSH pretty much just used this game as a template for creating planets in Space Engineers(which is a FAR better game by the way, it has a "somewhat decent" player base, gets updated regularly, has MUCH more to do, ect).After planets were introduced to Space Engineers, Keen Software House pretty much cut off Medieval Engineers like it was a leg with severe gangrene.I wanted to like this game. But as it is, there is simply no substance, no gameplay, just mindless building. It would be fun if there was a dedicated RP server with huge bustling cities and alot of players, but you will never find that here.     Buy Space Engineers instead.     Even then I can't promise you will get your moneys worth of gameplay.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
23 minutes played is all i needed to give this game a huge thumbs up.Pro's Very impressed with how optimized it is despite its infancy as a project, I experienced frame drops as i pin pointed my cannon balls to key locations to bring down the entire castle at once, however I am running a 6 year old i7-950 with a GTX 660, with the graphics set to max. I honestly expected lockups w/ all those physics calculations, not mere frame drops. I was surprised how attractive the landscape, especially considering all Keen has done for years is build large rocks Keen Software House is a bright spot on the muck that is early access games, Space Engineers has had a wonderful development cycle and the developers have proven they are competent and capable of acheiving the goals that were paying money for Very reasonably priced right now at $15, I would had paid this for the blowing things up aspect aloneCon's Currently the only aspect is building and blowing things up. do not buy this if you expect a survivorlist mode on par with SE (yet) If your computer is potato powered the physics based rendering system in this game is not going to go well, however i feel relunctant to list this as a con because its 2015 and you could go and build a PC capable of crushing this game for $800SummaryBuy this game, support these guys, they truely deserve it. If you are at all skeptical because you have never heard of them before, just check out the update logs for Space Engineers, their other project, I am confident all your worries will be laid to rest.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								A good building game, with realistic physics (most of the time) , a growing pallette of blocks to choose from, active updates and more! Although I have yet to really find the best ways to utilize the mechanism parts, I've had a blast making my first proper fortification, and look forward to what they bring out next. The pvp capabilities do seem a little limited, but with the addition of the crossbow it's definitely a lot more possible in the terms of the siege scenarios. Would recomend to any friend interested in building, while I would wait to alert those looking for pvp, aside from castle destruction.*Pros-Good selection of blocks-Beautiful scenery-Realistic physics and destruction-Creative tools are a huge boon *Cons-Higher requirements limit the numbers during sieges-Pvp isn't optimized, but on it's way*Suggestions-Team owned bots (Archers acting simmilar to the turrets perhaps?)-Better gear system to optimize moving energy from power source (windmill) to mechanism (Gate / drawbridge / trap/ etc)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Played a little bit of this and the building is certainly fun, though getting used to the controls (especially ground leveling) takes a while to do. Impressive in the structures you can build in it, especially for an Early Access, and I'm sure it will continue to grow as features are added in.That being said, the features I would very much like to see added:-Gathering: We can knock down trees, but... do what with them?-Planting: I'd like to be able to create a forest where I'd want it.-Water (rivers/lakes): Seriously my biggest glaring issue was that the fields have no water. Castles are almost -never- built without a water supply nearby. Would like to be able to place springs to start river flows through channels. (I know this is a difficult one, fluid physics in a game tend to be the most difficult ones, but it feels like a dead world without it).

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Keen Software House did it again, I thoroughly enjoy my time being spent with Medieval Engineers along with Space Engineers. the latter is spectacular and now this....... this just amazes me with all the potential it brings boys and girls.Medivieval Engineers is a voxel based game with the newly added terriforming capabilities that gives the correct tools to bring ones gaming experience to a new level. build a castle, homestead, or reanimate landscapes that you could only dream of. The building is excellent with easy to use instructions and hotkeys, have four different sets of customeizable keys at your will to make what you please. I am eagerly waiting for the RELIABLE updates these guys bring and the loyal development they bring to the table(been here since SE launch). Keensoftware house builds games, communties, and friends without effert due to there hard earned ethics. if you second guess alpha launches or early acces develpment, there is nothing to worry about here, join in and have fun, watch this baby grow into a giant!

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								Despite the fact this game is in early access and still under heavy development, It's early features and physics never seize to amaze so early early on in the games development.For me, when it comes it Medieval Engineers, the only thing more fun than building a castle is destroying a castle, and the game developers have perfected just that. With the Infrastructure setting enabled, too much weight on top of something or   destableization of the bottom part of a structure will compromise It's integrity, and cause it to topple to the ground leaving nothing but I gient pile of rubble. When this reaction occours on a large scale, it could make you lag untill all the rubble has stoped tumbling.At the games current state, I admit there is not too many blocks to use, and also there is not yet Multiplayer, but I am certain they will release it soon, as in Space engineers. You could be reading this many updates into the future, where Multiplayer and a lot more things have bean introduced.Overall, Medieval engineers is a fantastic game, and whenever you may be reading this, there are still many more updates to come!

								I'd like to point out that while I do have a AMD FX 8350 8 core clocked at 4.3Ghz, 32Gb RAM, the GTX 660 I have only has 2Gb video ram. Even on the lowest settings, I've had lagging issues. Mainly when objects break and fall. It's not little objects, it's the large number of objects that are in motion. The grass and flower animations are unaltered. Trees break fine without issues. It's when I smash stone walls or other thick and large objects. Other than that, the game is fun, but is better played with friends.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is an early access game so it's not anywhere near complete yet and what features it does have do have some glitches.  However, it gets updated every week and is already a lot of fun.  It satisfies 2 primal urges:  the need to build your own caslte, and the need to destroy castles.  Doesn't everybody want to do that?Just don't get too attached to anything you make right now, or rely on mods, because it's quite likely, probably a certainty, that changes to the game will break your stuff on a regular basis.  But that's OK because they've got a lot of blocks to add still, and those will make your old stuff obsolete anyway.So go ahead and get it.  You'll enjoy it.  Just be sure to read the help screen, watch the tutorials, watch user videos, and check the forums for help and solutions.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								(Understand that I am doing a review about the "Early Access" version, it's still under construction as we speak)When "Space Engineers" came out, it's one of the best "Sandbox" style games I have ever played. Games like "Rollercoaster Tycoon", "Theme Hospital", and "Theme Park" are nothing compaired to the idea that it's SO MUCH BETTER when you are able to make the buildings, mechanics, and animations yourself. Who cares if you can build a "pre-made" building, making the building itself with all the animations is so much more rewarding because you, the designer, made the building yourself.Now, the people that brought you "Space Engineers" goes and makes this game, "Medieval Engineers".  If you ever wanted to make your own castle, village, or small settlement, and design it however YOU wanted it to look like, now you actually can. Set up a small location, build a small village with a blacksmith, Inn, store, farm, or build your ideal castle. The game itself has enough mechanics to be able to build whatever you need, however you want it to look. You can use stone blocks or wood blocks with either stone or wood platforms, walls, stairs, ceilings, roofs, and so much more. There's even mechanical devices you can use to make such things as windmills, cranks, even design your own contraptions such as catapults, on wheels even.Every effort has been made to create "realism" in every way. Personally, my only reason for getting this game was because I loved "Speace Engineers". This game is now my second love. If you have played "Space Engineers", then you can't go wrong with this. Designing just got better. Just like "space Engineers", it's about what you want to build, how you wanted to look. [OH FOR PEEK SAKES, JUST GET THE GAME AND START BUILDING ALREADY] ^_^

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								Let's get this out of the way: This game is not even remotely close to being in a state that meets the expectations you might have after watching the video trailers. You are extremely limited in what you can do at this time.Essentially, you only have 'creative mode' available to you at this moment, but if Keen updates this with the same pacing and quality of Space Engineers, then you can expect frequent and awesome changes to come hard and fast. DAY 1 Pros: -Textures (even if placeholders) are beautiful and rich. The forest landscape reminds me of Elder Scrolls Oblivion. -DirectX 11 and multithreading offer stability and  terrific multiplayer opportunities down the road.-Destruction is very well designed and the physics seems solid. Day 1 Cons:-If the projectiles are the same mass and velocity to the eventual siege weapons, then stone walls will need to be a lot more durable, because right now they seem to be as strong as cardboard. -No multiplayer or survival at day one. This is expected, but I just want it to be obvious if you are going to buy the game based on that. -A distinct lack of goats. Summary: Game has extremely high amounts of potential and is already fun to tinker about inside the world. Software company that makes it is very considerate of their players and will update frequently and deliver.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game, is fun. When I got in I tried to make a catapult... then realized I dont know how. It may seem similer to spaceengineers, because it was made by the same people, but its pretty diferent , even in very early alpha/beta.  right now all you can do is playaround in singleplayer creative, but when the suvival, and multiplayer come out, this game will be amazing. I actually like the building alot more in this than in space engineers. The reason for that being you have to think about how are you going to build it first. I found myself actually going as far as planning out the shape, size, and even were the supports were going to be. The only thing better than building a wonderfull building, is watching as that same wonderfull building crumbles to the ground.Another thing, if you are going straight from space engineers to this, you WILL need to watch the tutorial video for the game. The bulding system is similer, yet different. different in the fact that you can place multiple blocks in the same block, and there is structual intefrety. While structual integrety is toggelable, via the world edit menu, if you want to build somthing nice, you have to learn the mechanics.overal score = I expect more from this than space engineers (10/10)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								- - - -I will update this review as the game updates. Most recent review update: 3/3/15- - - -This game is incredible and exactly what I paid for. A game stressed upon physics that has near limitless capabilities, based upon construction, destruction, rinse and repeat. 8/10, but since it came out only a few days ago, I'd say it deserves those extra points for being this fantastic right from the get-go. If you want an awesome game, buy now. If you want a game you'll(or at least I'll) play for the rest of your life after a few months period of updates, Buy. Now. All in all, there are some drawbacks, but it's almost 98% positive fun gameplay. That is, if your "Fun" includes architectural design and physics used to demolish everything in sight.+Positive++Even the medium graphics are incredible. If you have a tough system, please play on the highest graphics possible, for the beauty of the scenery is astounding. +30 points+The physics engine is to DIE for. I've been craving a game of this caliber for my entire life. Want a bridge that splits in the middle and slides into sockets? Do it. Want a machine gun catapult? Do. It. Want a rope suspended bridge that rebounds against cannon balls? Do. +70 points+The versatility of what you can make is awe-inspiring. You could make a system of pulleys and winches that operates 20 catapults surrounding a castle to demolish it in one fell swoop(or alternatively, miss with every single one and destroy your beautiful catapults.). +40 points+Realizing what I've said earlier, I'd like to build upon it all. Since windmills are most definitely usable, you could make. A fully automated, wind powered line of catapults that reloads itself and launches projectiles infinitely until it runs out of ammo. +(does this even count)10 points+It just came out and it's this good already. Also, frequent updates. +50 points+Barbarians are cool and the fact that they were added in earlier than they should have is good to see their mechanics beforehand and find good ways to build defendable fortresses before their AI gets revamped. +10 points-Negative-These points generally have more written, but that's because they need more explaining.-Long loading times, but this is expected if you've played Space Engineers, and isn't really a problem once you've got a world loaded. -5 points-Lag. If you have a system with generally low specs, you might want to consider getting a new computer to play, or taking countermeasures to weaken the game's stress on your speed. However, having a low-end computer myself, the lag is not unbearable, and fully understandable considering the powerful physics engine. -10 points, though this is only a user-related issue. If you have a strong system, BUY.-One of the core reasons there is so much lag is the worlds. Sure, the forests look beautiful, but I'm in creative mode. Shouldn't I get a choice of a very small world with no forests? The trees and the rest of the world are a source of great lag, while I am trying to build a trebuchet to demolish this finely structured building in front of me. Smaller worlds are needed. -30 points-No legitimate hands-on tools/weapons. What I mean is this: Space Engineers had player-wielded machine gun rifles, yes? Then these engineers should get swords. I want to sword fight on my castle as it crumbles. Obviously this shouldn't be stressed until multiplayer comes, or DEFINITELY when true NPC raiding parties come. Also, the raiding parties should not be limited to swords, they should get at least simple siege weaponry i.e. a catapult they pull with them. Also, when these NPCs do come around, ideally they should be able to take keeps and/or spawn in keeps with the map, so they can be raided and taken over. -5 points-There is a moderately bad bug involving broken stone cubes, I believe it is due to parts of the stone cubes that DO break getting partially lodged in the unbroken parts, keeping them both elevated and preventing you from placing blocks for repairs unless you damage the block further yourself(which can cause more damage to the surrounding area) and dig a hole underneath, place a block so that the physics reload and the fragments fall, and fill the hole back up, all so you can make repairs. Also, sometimes the fragments that are stuck midair cannot even be broken. This is but a small bug however, and I pretty much covered the whole thing in that paragraph. -5 points (Partially fixed the bug. You go, guys!)After all that, still +155 points.The best part of all of it? Mindless destruction. And why that is the best part is that it's not even mindless. It takes full consciousness and mental focus to build a machine capable of laying waste to fortresses from afar. Thank you, thank you for this wonderful gift of a game. And I thought SPACE Engineers was good. Compared to this, I'd say SE is half the game this is/will be.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Keen Software House is the best example of Early Access you can get! They keep in contact with the community. They make meaningful updates weekly. They are very honest and open about their plans and direction with the game, and best of all THEIR GAME WORKS! Medieval Engineers -- aside from some bugs and optimization -- is already at a state where they could go full release! The building mechanics are solid and it doesn't take long before you're making your dream castle! They give you enough tools to let your imagination run wild, especially the blocks within blocks tool! Compound blocks allows you to invent new blocks on the fly to suit your design, making you have that extra level of detail to any creatoin. The added structural integrity mode makes building feel more like a challenge. You have to be aware of how much weight is being placed on certain blocks. It adds an air of tension while you're building, "Oh gosh will this block be the one to ruin my castle?" The game gets a new sense of tension in this mode and I love it for this! This game is a near perfect and its not even finished! Keep going Keen Software House! You are the reason for Early Access!

Wood, wood bark, and stone. I also looked at it and sighed, knowing that it would be destroyed relatively soon by pirates or something. Don't buy if you like making progress in survival quickly, or like building cool things quickly

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								For those who are looking at this game because they loved Space Engineers:Think hard before buying this one. In fact, if you're going to buy it, read up on how to play a little bit first, then buy it and dive in so you can get a good taste before you hit the two hours mark. That way you can return it for a refund if you don't care for it.This game is simply too rudimentary and clunky if you're already used to Space Engineers—it feels like this game was branched off from SE and then it was never able to catch up. The survival mode is sorely lacking in polish, but if you are a  creative mode-only player then you won't mind. The controls are inexplicably awkward for a SE veteran. You'll have as much stutter as on a SE planet, and there's no space mode to save you from it here.This game can still shine for you depending on what you're looking for, but the odds are against it so go in prepared to eject and perhaps you'll be pleasantly surprised.

Lets say it like this:The Idea is Good real good and it does bring some invonation ... to the world of KSW Gameing (Why am i saying this? Well its Keen Software House Quality ... Greybox XD Joking! No Serisously their games a great) ... in a rather bad than good term when you ask me.Gameplay: Its Plays very hard even in Creative as even when its finaly working for maybe a minute or so ... its hard to figure anything out that works as most of the stuff Literly Destoryes itself By A) Exploding or B) Crashing the game. Not to mention that anything larger than a Medium House (Normal Size = 10x10x10 for me) can slow you game down.AI: Stupid ... nuff said and its stupid ... its sometimes helpful but mostly annoying.Gamemodes: -Creative ... a Buggy mess wich is actualy the most working part of the game ... if it werent for the complete misplaced Button or Keys (Said by a Regular Space Engineers Player)-Survival ... dont try it with and Without Barbarians ... it makes the already Hard Creative up to a Way to hard Survival ... its nearly Unplayable as its not Only Boring as hell but also barely works as storage comes in chests wich ... arent implemented in Survival Yet ... i think but even if they are they can at max store 10 Stones so its a waste. And if you look at the Time i played you can trust me when i said that i already forced me to find something in this game wich isnt frustrateing or Crashing the game right away. Currently its somewhat a Waste of Money ... i would give it a Prize of5.99€ For the Quality it has.

content:

Early Access Review
								This is something that I've wanted for the longest of time, but I just cannot play it. The control scheme is so difficult to use, it feels as though it could be made a lot more user friendly. The movement is also not great; why does the walking have a head-bob? It's not necessary at all. It just makes the placement of objects that much more difficult. The fly mode seems to use an accleration, that could possibly be done better? I'm not too sure, again it just makes the placement of objects that much more difficult. Another thing, why the need for combat and combat NPCs, etc? Why not just leave it at building, I mean it's in the title. If you have the time and patience to learn the control scheme and deal with the clunky movement, then I wholeheartedly recommend this game but for me, those two aspects are key in a building sim and they fall short.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								Medieval Engineers, although in early access and only being on the shelf for less than a year has enough content to keep me entertained for hours, if it's putting on a podcast and building a huge castle for 3 hours, or downloading other castles from the Steam Workshop and tearing them down with custom build catapults and trebuchets, or maybe trying to survive wave after wave of barbarain attacks at night, and rebuilding in the day. I still have fun doing it. It's core elements would be:*Build as much as your computer can handle *Epic, softbody destruction *Old, over looked genre setting (atleast for a sandbox building game)*Semi regular updates adding bug fixes, new blocks, ect.*Workshop support *Mod support (mods can also be found from the Steam workshop*Major replayability (I come back to this game pretty regularly and when I do it's for hours on end.)*Massive planets you can walk around completley with out loading screens (granted it would probably take you a few hours.)*Different factions to compete with friends *Mutiplayer, allthough in the interest of full disclosure it is fairly buggy and can end with the game crashing.   Yes, this game is glitchy, buggy, it may crash for placing a block wrong, but playing it since it came out I have seen more and more of those bugs go away and the physics engine get more stable. But this game has been out less than a year and is still in early access, yet it has more content and is better crafted than most the early access games on Steam combined. If you're like me who can't get enough of sandbox building games and can look over a few bugs for the meantime then you'll love this. P.S.After seeing all these negitive reviews I thought I should add something else to my review. I've been playing Medeival Engineers since day 1 of launch, I've been following and playing Keen House Software's other game Space Engineers since the Alpha stage, that means I've had plenty of time to play and get to know the games of KHS, and from what I've seen is massive dedication to the games, (One of the first devs to bring weekly updates every Thursday) listening to the players and changing the game to suit everybody, (planets were never going to be a thing in SE or ME, yet the devs managed to put them in after massive fan feedback.)    So to all the people saying they don't listen to players and have quit this game for good, only trying to make a quick buck, you're wrong. At the time of writing KHS has had to stop weekly updates for ME and smaller 'dev builds' for SE this is purely because it takes time just to make the video showing new blocks and features, let alonet the time and thought process needed to implement new features. But as they have shown, it's been well worth the wait due to ME now offically having plants, female engineers, new blocks, ect ect. Just because the Devs go silent for a few days does not mean they've quit the game, after the work KHS has done in the past years I think it's safe to say you can have a little faith in them.

								With the recent update ME has become a game, rather than just a sandbox only.Still quite buggy, but I find I can play just fine.It would be nice if there were some permenant official servers. The server situation is a bit hit and miss right now.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								I was reserving my review until the planet update came out so here we go…More than a simple update, what we had here is a whole new start for the game, under the lead of a new team leader, and I must say that it definitely took a step in the right direction.Before this update/relaunch, what you had was more a sandbox than an actual game. It really looked promising as the building mechanics were very interesting and game many creative possibilities.Now, they have introduced these mechanics inside a multiplayer environment where factions, wars, siege and territorial domination are involved and I must say that it is already very interesting.Don’t get me wrong, as it is now, the whole thing is no more than a preliminary draft of what we will have in several months, there some bugs and many fundamental gameplay mechanisms still have to be implemented/changed but it is already very fun.It is also clear that the team is very active. Not only that, but it also listens to the community and actually answer in the forums, this is very encouraging.So, to sum up, this is still not a polished and flawless game, don’t expect this, but there is a huge potential and I believe that the development will be very fast paced form now on.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								You will get a bunch of people, many of which are barely literate, who will tell you that this game is a cash in. That the developers are pouring out unfinished games to get the moola. But I don't see this being the case, not while features are being implemented to both games to complement the development. People will tell you that this is the reason they half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥Space Engineers, but then again these people were the ones who took frequent updates for granted. Though the game hasn't got too much, which was the case with SE, it is enjoyable if you enjoy building with an added challenge. The game allows you build out fantasy or medieval settings to your heart's content but with the fact these buildings must be constructed with structural integrity in mind.  Due to that system, the destruction of the buildings are incredibly satisfying... or heartbreaking, depending on what side of the wall you're on.  Not forgetting a pully system that puts your medieval engineering to the test with elaborate gates, mechanisms and siege weaponry.The game has a lot of potential in the terms of PVP, Roleplay and Sandbox pleasure you might find in similar games. To say the least, they have added a fresh taste to this somewhat bloated genre. I just hope they make a decent survival element to it all.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is wonderful. Even in the current unpolished state, the game is addictive and hits a chord that few other games can hit. The destruction physics are entertaining and challenging. The desire to build is constantly driven by "how big can I make this" and "how can I hit this with a cannonball and make it fall". As features continue to expand, I expect to see this game become a wonderful gem of the gaming world. I would disreguard most of the negative reviews on here because they seem to have missed the point that this game is in extremely early stages. For it to function as it does with the minimal bugs and issues is very impressive. As well, the dev team is extremely invested and dedicated to giving the community what they want. The collaborations between the Medieval and Space engineers devs is something of a golden goose. Expect to see a lot of wonderful new content in Space Engineers as well as ME. If you are truly interested in this game, don't hesitate, support the devs now and save yourself some cash. You won't regret it.(Also disreguard the lack of hours as I have been extremely busy and haven't been able to play as much as I wish.)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Do you want to build castles, houses, towers, windmills, and other medieval structures? Get this gameDo you want to randomly destroy the things you built, by either just chucking boulders at things, or setting up catapults, etc?  Get this gameDo you want to essentially press x and activate your 'jetpack' in creative mode?  Get this gameDo you want to follow weekly updates from KSH and their awesome update system?  Get this gameAll of that being said, this game is still very early access, there are a lot of things to be done.  There is no survival mode, but the things for it are essentially there, and you can see it all coming together.  You do not have to build on a plane if you wish not to, as there is a new dynamic construction mode.  Definite fun, especially with a friend, the possibilites are endless.  Ill be watching development closely to decide when to start a server.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								Lets start with the good I suppose:This game has a lot of promise. The possibilities for what you can do with this game are seemingly endless. Like its sister product, Space Engineers, you can build almost anything that you can imagine. The game makes you think about how something should go to gether to make it work and be stable. Unlike SE, you get the chance to use physics and structural integrity to guide your building and creating. This game also allows you to destroy creations, with great destruction animations and effects. This game has a lot of potential, and I am eagerly awaiting the next update.Now its time for the Bad, as everything has a pro and con.The dev's have decided to "temporarily" delay updates so that the engineers of the game can create and develop without the stressors of having to meet a weekly quota. This seemed fine to me at the beginning, but that was back in May and we have yet to recieve a single update, and it is now August. The "Dev Diaries" seem to showcase a lot of realy cool and interesting stuff, but we can't actually interact with any of the changes. There is no "Development Build" for the consumers, aka the people who paid for this game, to actually enjoy anything that they are making. I have the dev build for space engineers, but none available for medieval engineers, which I honestly enjoy playing more. I understand that the dev's have a lot to do and a few major overhauls of the game, but going three, almost four months without an update, while space engineers is still recieving one every week is kind of a slap in the face to the consumer. Overall I would recommend this game, because even in it's current buggy, unfinished, jittery state this game can still be enjoyable. I have high hopes and expectations for what the dev's have been working on for three months, and I really hope that they will release either a dev build or an update that covers at least some of what they have been working on.Current state rating will have to be a 4/10 overall, but with what the dev diary has showcased I could give this game an 8/10.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								Quite a fun take on medieval physics.  And by that, I don't mean magic ... but rather a nicely filled out physics engine that implements what they call "structural integrity".  Take a cannonball to a tower,  and it logically takes damage.  That is, load bearing walls, when hit, cause the loads they are bearing to fall, as well.Quite an entertaining early access game.  I look forward to being able to play it multiplayer!

content:
Posted: January 3
Early Access Review
								When I first saw this game I knew that I had to have it, so I did. The reason why I came to such a quick conclusion was that in the first videos of release they gave such broad and unbelievable promises that I knew that I couldnt miss out. Now the first problem you might have to my conclusion would be that promises are not always kept. To that I say, look at their other game Space Engineers which I also have and as far as I can tell they do keep the promises they make. So, lets get into the loves and wishes I have with this game. First of all I love the unique building where you can combine different blocks in the same voxel although there are a few bugs where you cant put them together, but with time I am sure they will be fixed. The worlds are just the right size, but I really would love biomes which I expect they will add. Also the clan system they have is great, but I would like a bit more of an incentive to attack others. Keeping with the clans I wish there were barbarian clans  in single-player and maybe even multi-player that fight each other and you with a bit more than a sword and pickaxe.(Maybe catapults and trebuches) I like the system of mining, but I dont like the long wait in between destruction of the terrain which Im pretty sure they said they would fix. I like how you can destory much of the land, but I hope they will add a way to add land in survival. Getting away from that I enjoy the NPCs, and cant wait to be able to get them in survival. Now getting into the topic I dread, but am hopeful about ,Multi-player. Multi-player is in a state that doesnt really work at the moment, but they are trying to make it better which gives me assurance that one day it will be very bearable to play with others.(Maybe even fun and enjoyable) All in all there are many things I would like, but if you are hesitant to buy this games then either wait for more updates or get it now, although I would definitely get it in the end game.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								I bought this game the day before the relaunch, and the difference is night and day.  Yes the game is still incomplete in many areas, but is now a whole lot more fun and a lot less frustrating. There are now reasons to explore the planet and stake out your own claim, build up your house and castle, and pillage other players.  The online experience is incredibly stable for Space Engineers and Medieval Engineers.  At the launch stream, we got 79 players all on one server and the game still ran.  You obviously need good hardware to host a game of that size, but the game itself is remarkably stable.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								Game has potential, I did recieve it for free. So yea it has optimization issues, but what game doesn't that is trying to achieve something more than what's already been seen and done. For any of you stating that the game should already be optimized and blah blah blah, that's like saying ARK should've been optimized before release. Yet, ARK is still Overwhelmingly Positive reviews. Only reason why this game has gone to hell is the lost of content and updates. It's a lost project since it's brother Space Engineers has become much more successful. Not getting paid anything to post this positive review so don't hate. I really don't care to hear anymore trolls, but I do wish that I could've seen what this game would've been if it actually was paid more attention to. R.I.P Medieval Engineers, you were the start of the next gen games, and now you will be forever forgotten, and if not forgotten, remembered as a crap game.Developers, I wish I could've seen the game completed. Sucks that you just dropped it, and didn't finish what you started. I understand Space Engineers is much more successful, but this game could've too. You guys took the easy way out. A lot of people paid money for this is was left with a game %40 complete. I am surprised that a lot of people bought your brother game since you guys just dropped this one. Got lucky if you ask me.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								Okay i have only just gotten around playing the game, despite having it for a long time.I love it!The idea is grate, and most of the mechanics that have been worked on are grate, like the building sytem which is a lot better then 6 a year a go, and by a lot i mean a lot.You do need to toy around in sandbox to get an idea of what you are doing, but once you understand how thing work i is pretty fun to play around.A hidden gem is survival, i did not expect it to be so... enjoyable. Yes it needs work (my axe sticking out of my face as if i was using the crossbow) and oh god inventory space becomes a problem early in the game.It is not as smooth as space engineers of course, but it is a game that is going, i feel, in a different direction; the recently added fast travel system kind of makes me feel that way.Oce you get past the standard trebutchet design you are left looking at the blocks wondering what elese can you do, and trust me, just look around the workshop for someome of the crazy stuff come up with.I can understand the frustration of people, some of the bugs of a year ago are still there etc. but if i were to compare to space engineers, id say the same happened.To the devs i say, right now it feels like when you just added rotors in space engineers, or at least it gives me that feel. still cluncky but going forewards. The reviews you are getting latley is just people hungering for more, especially if you can work your magick like you did with space engineers.Yhis game has so much potential and it is already grate it just needs constant work. To you DEVS i say, well done.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Is this game worth it? In its current state, no, but thumbs up for potential. If you really want it, get it on sale.With the multiplayer function, you and your friends can build quite the castle, or fort, or whatever cool thing. No special setup is needed to host, so you just need a good PC and decent internet. Plus, you can conduct seiges, which are fun.The structural integrity is cool, and you won't have trouble building. However, it's a little generous on the strength, so things somethimes don't crumble as you'd want them too, or don't reflect what they would actually do.You can build tunnels, and if you had the patience, you could make a full town underground. If you're digging a basement with a pickaxe, then you need to be careful because if you head to the bottom of your hole and turn around, you risk falling through the ground, which then you must kill yourself and lose everything of value on hand.Again, good game, but wait for it to develope more before buying.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Is this game worth it? In its current state, no, but thumbs up for potential. If you really want it, get it on sale.With the multiplayer function, you and your friends can build quite the castle, or fort, or whatever cool thing. No special setup is needed to host, so you just need a good PC and decent internet. Plus, you can conduct seiges, which are fun.The structural integrity is cool, and you won't have trouble building. However, it's a little generous on the strength, so things somethimes don't crumble as you'd want them too, or don't reflect what they would actually do.You can build tunnels, and if you had the patience, you could make a full town underground. If you're digging a basement with a pickaxe, then you need to be careful because if you head to the bottom of your hole and turn around, you risk falling through the ground, which then you must kill yourself and lose everything of value on hand.Again, good game, but wait for it to develope more before buying.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								well I bought and installed it lastnight, and I was kinda discouraged by the slow pace and odd building style so I turned the game off and went and watched some movies. Later on I turned it back on just to give it another try before I think about the waste of money I am going to uninstall like so many others. That's when we (me and the game) just clicked, something magical happened that lured me in, and now 5 hours later at 5am I have a giant castle wall a very nice farmhouse with horse stables and a working windmill... As of now I don't want to put the game down but I have to go to sleep for work in the afternoon. The game itself doesn't have much to it as of yet, no NPC's, no multiplayer, no sort of interaction at all. But what it does have is beautiful graphics, sweet mechanics, good ole fashioned creative mode with quite a few different starter maps, and the ability to teraform entire mountains or sling cannonballs at whatever creation you make (or the provided premade buildings). Pick it up while it's on sale, it's well worth the price, heck I'd even pay full price for it because I've seen the hard work the devs have put into Space Engineers and I'm sure this one's going to come along nicely.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								Okay i have only just gotten around playing the game, despite having it for a long time.I love it!The idea is grate, and most of the mechanics that have been worked on are grate, like the building sytem which is a lot better then 6 a year a go, and by a lot i mean a lot.You do need to toy around in sandbox to get an idea of what you are doing, but once you understand how thing work i is pretty fun to play around.A hidden gem is survival, i did not expect it to be so... enjoyable. Yes it needs work (my axe sticking out of my face as if i was using the crossbow) and oh god inventory space becomes a problem early in the game.It is not as smooth as space engineers of course, but it is a game that is going, i feel, in a different direction; the recently added fast travel system kind of makes me feel that way.Oce you get past the standard trebutchet design you are left looking at the blocks wondering what elese can you do, and trust me, just look around the workshop for someome of the crazy stuff come up with.I can understand the frustration of people, some of the bugs of a year ago are still there etc. but if i were to compare to space engineers, id say the same happened.To the devs i say, right now it feels like when you just added rotors in space engineers, or at least it gives me that feel. still cluncky but going forewards. The reviews you are getting latley is just people hungering for more, especially if you can work your magick like you did with space engineers.Yhis game has so much potential and it is already grate it just needs constant work. To you DEVS i say, well done.

content:
