Early Access Review
								I do reccomend this game;in it's current state (just been released) you can already mod the game and it has full workshop support.The developers are one of the best there has been for quite some time, if the community really wants a particular update, the developers will add it, the next thursday. Currently you can build catapults and trubuchets and drawbridges and anything else you can come up with that is mechanical and involving wieghts, ropes and rotating wood.The destruction is also very nice, the block crumble into chunks and look very pretty.  the game overall looks very pretty in fact. And, if you have played KSHs other game: space engineers, you will know how satisfying it is to build an impressive contraption or building and know that it works.However, It is still a little glitchy (a lot of the glitches can be sorted by youself very easily (a whole bunch were fixed in the last patch). The game runs fairly well and if you can't, the graphics presets, while basic, do offer a decent change in performance at each stage.Overall, This game is definately reccomended by me, and if it is updated as frequently as space engineers is (the developers have promised they will) then this game could become a favourite for many.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								The soundtrack is really what makes or breaks a game; this is one of those games that the music is phenominal. It has the nostalgic feel of medieval styled instruments, and never before has it felt so epic to build and explore. I can't help but compare this to Minecraft; the building is extensive and entertaining, as Minecraft very well achieved, however this game has the music that makes the game brilliant. Not too much content so far, but I'm sure in a couple months it's gonna be stock full with content.The graphics aren't too bad; they have a Skyrim like feel to them and the scenery looks gorgeous even on low. The game isn't really optimised yet, destroying walls makes my graphics lag. I have a decent graphics card and I hope that the game will get optimisation.What's even better is this is coming from a developer that you can trust; Space Engineers has been out for about a year and every week there's still updates coming out. Just to reassure those who believe that now that this game has come out, Space Engineers is abandoned; that is false. The company who brought you the Engineers games have two teams working on both of the games, each meritting the same style of great game. These 'Engineers' games have been an interesting expirience for I know not just me, but for thousands, if not millions of people worldwide.***Review is Subject to Change***9/10Nice graphicsMinimal bugsGreat interfaceFantastic sceneryBrilliant gameplay

content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Medieval Engineers is absolutely beautiful and Keen is a developer that follows through on continuous updates and listening to the community.  Unfortunately, right now I wouldn't recommend this game.  There's just not much going on (vanilla version, which I base reviews off of).  You want to build a castle? great.  You want derpy servants that might actually be up to par with medieval intelligence?  Also yes.  Do you want contraptions that actually make sense in a physics based environment?  Maybe someday.For now it's all about the looks and sadly its mechanical blocks fall short of even minecrafts simplistic design.  Still, I have faith in Keen and will be glad to change this review to a plus after a few updates which add real content.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								I love space engineers and it's the most played game in my library, when medieval engineers came out I bought it without hesitation, and in the state it was at release it was nigh unplayable.I've never been able to get into medieval engineers. It's just not as good as space engineers, infact it's down right boring. The building is needlessly complex compaired to space engineers to the point where it's not fun or interesting, it's annoying.The AI bots you can spawn in are stupid as hell, and are almost completely incapable of completing the simple tasks they were designed for. You'll tell a bot to chop up a tree and it'll sit there swinging at the ground and digging itself into a hole it then can't escape from. The AI bots are a completely worthless feature that flat out does not work and has never worked since it's implementation.Trying to place something as simple as a wall for example is a MASSIVE annoyance. Between toggling settings, trying to find the sweet spot where the wall can be planted, you need to get right up ontop of the spot you want to place the wall but not too close cause then you can't place it.  It's god damned annoying and frusterating to build anything at all. When compared to how easy it is to snap blocks together and build complex structures in space engineers, it is inexcusable that medieval engineers makes it such a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ I want to love this game, as much as I love space engineers, but it's not fun in the slightest, it's just annoying. Every few patches I poke my head back in to see if it's gotten any better and it continues to be unacceptably underwhelming and frusterating to do anything. So I'm finally just uninstalling the game, I loved space engineers so much that this game had nigh unshakeable faith from me that it would eventually get better and be just as fun, but I was wrong.

content:
Posted: January 30
Early Access Review
								I'm a huge fan of things medieval...I'm also a huge fan of Keen and think they're the best, most honest devs out there who always listen to players and add things in their games they never planned on doing themselves. That said, I'll try not being biased. I'll also try keeping this from being too long.ME is early access...that you should know immediately. Though it's not complete, it has a fully functioning Survival mode with at least some decent amount of content that's more than just harvesting resources to build with. Along with that, here's a more detailed list of some things currently in game (which will probably change tomorrow and the week after and so on):-real physics. Watch castles and towns crumble to the ground under their own weight or from projectiles hurled through the air-a failly detailed crafting system...i.e. gather iron ore for smelter, take ingots to smithy, grab sticks and other objects from the forests and ground to complete items, ect.-Houses and banners which make online a lot more fun especially for role-playing. Gather your friends under one banner and declare war on enemy territories.-voxel based terrain to modify worlds or builds in creative to come up with endless creative ideas-grid-based construction that's also dynamic...this isn't like Minecraft. You build single structures on their own grid, but different structures can face any angle you'd like-Farming! This is a nice recent addition to the game and greatly enhances survival play and playing with friends.If you're creative and like medieval times, you could have endless fun on here. Keen updates every week on Tuesday and to give you an idea of early access, thier other game Space Engineers only recently (late 2016) hit official 'beta' status on Steam, after like 3 years in early access. This game is about to hit 2 years old in Feb. That means at least about 60 more updates to look foward to, which may include a wide range of new blocks tools or items, game mechanics, AI additions or changes, and more before it could hit official beta. And then it'll still be updated after that to continue making it a full game. And honestly, I think this one has a lot more potential than SE did.

								i can reccomend this, but i have a few downsides to point out:Pros:CastlesCatapultssmaking barbarians from very high placesCons:Bad combat mechanicsneed a beefy computer to runphysics engine needs a sort of lag proofing (in castle seige i kept dieing due to clipping into the machines)Toll range needs fixing or the graphic needs to be fixed (either one would do so that when im trying to break somthing down i can tell if im hitting it or not)EDIT: Another notable glitch is where in castle seige you sometimes faze out of existance completely. this is a game-breaking glitch that should be fixed as soon as possible. content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								The early release is amazing. There are a few obvious bugs to be scratched quickly but so far this game is already amazing. Unlike Space Engineers I hope this game will become more of a multiplayer survival base game instead of just the space simulator that Space Engineers has been recently. The breaking is amazing and the integrety makes me a little wet but I just hope it doesn't all go to waste and become one of those games I play if I say "I wonder if I can..." rather than a game where I can say "Lets get on a server and make a castle I can defend!"I guess my point here is that space engineers is big on making things never seen with the tools at hand and while I love that about it I hope this game will be playable in survival strongly enough that there will be servers with average players that just want to build and be in a community.Oh btw, 10/10 for an early release. If you enjoy destroying large building that took hours to build you're either going to love it a lot or hate it a lot depending on wether or not you meant to destroy it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game.... oh this game!!Let's start off by saying that this is in Early access so expect some things to be weird at times.. However with that said I see this game being one of the best building/engineering game once it's finished.  The physics in this game are what sets it apart from a lot of other building games.  What also makes it unique is the ability to engineer all types of machines and seige weapons for your castles using wood and different medieval enginnering gadgets and techniques.The structural integrity feature is what really makes this game fun but very difficult as well.  If your building can't support its weight then it will come crashing down and you will cry.  I cry a lot because I guess I suck at engineering.All in all this is a really fun game and Keen Software House kicks A$$ with updates weekly with new features and tons of fixes!  Buy this game while it's cheap.  You seriously won't regret it!!

Early Access Review
								do you hate it when early access leaves a bad taste in your mouth? Then try here. These devs are a wonderful example of how early can work. Space Engineers was constantly and frequently updated and improved. major game breaking bugs never survived longer than a week before they were hotfixed.  expect much of the same dedcation for this game.And this game is going to be a blast when it hits multiplayer. I have already had tones of fun smashing castles in creative and  can't wait to get this in survival. knowing these devs survival and multiplayer are a few months away not a few years.right at this moment this game is a very early version but it will get better and better in a timely manner.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								At first glance, I thought "Well, this looks pretty standard as far as building games go". I've played Space Engineers, and I loved it, and this just seemed like more of the same thing in a different setting. The game is definitely beautiful, as far as looks go, but it was just another typical game where you build things.But it's not. I just discovered "Compound building", which is a term I was unfamiliar with. I'd thought of the concept, and that it would be something I'd like in the many years I've played Minecraft, but I'd never seen a game that actually allowed it until this.Guys, it's literally blocks in blocks. You want that wood floor in the same block space as that stone wall? Compound building. It's so obvious that this feature should exist in everything, but somehow it hasn't until now.10/10 would build blocks in blocks again.

								After the Space Engineers got tired of building,blowing up, and crashing their designs, they decided to warp back somewhere from the 5th to 15th century time periods. Now with MORE to destroy and a very impressive integrity software, the Space Engineers dubbed themselves.....The Medieval Engineers! Okay now for what I think. FIX 2: There is not totaly realistic phisics, for example, when building a pillar of blocks then building to the side, you can build 10 blocks before it crumbles! PS: the last bit of my blocks were close to the ground.  Also my tower stood with a small support.  UNKOWN 3: On the map Bridges, the wagon makes the bridge crumble.  That shouldnt happen, because it has supports close to each other.  CRASH 4: When playing Bridges, my computer crashed.  Maybe its because I had graphics on presets  low and graghics qaulity on medium, medium is a bit laggy. SUJESTION 5: You should definetly add horses.  Also you should also make it were if a rope is attached to a rock, it shuold snap when under high G (Flying)  SUJJESTIION 6: You shuold add difrent blocks like cogs and gears and stone floors (Sideways variant of the stone wall) and wood panels (Sideways variant of the wooden floor).  Also you shuold add back in the catch blocks with block-type wood inside and add corner variants of the ceiling.  BUG 7:  Sometimes when deleting parts of a gate-type fashion (Wood in the fashion of the drawbridge) it flies, and it is realy easy to emplode when testing.  Also the drawbridges dont go down if as big as entrance with little stopers when retraced.I didnt realy know how to word my thoughts in the most part.Enderborn01

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								To be perfectly honest this game is one of my favorite games, It was JUST released and already it has an amazing building system, experimental AI and great destruction. The physics are a bit jenky but what can you expect from such an early game. One other problem I have is you can't rotate certain blocks upsidedown or sideways. There is no multiplayer as of yet but as I said before it was just released.The graphics are awesome and you should find no trouble running the game on medium (From my experience).You can edit the terrain using a nice voxel system and even make structures with it.You can build massive and beautiful structures with the even the basic blocks you have currently.Next I should talk about the mechanical machines side of Medieval Engineers.When searching for blocks to use you will find some mechanical bits and bobs, some of those are wheels, rope wheels, weight blocks and wooden rods (And more stuff besides). With this stuff you can build primitive vehicles, elevators, catapults and trebuchets!I have not tested or even looked at the AI in game yet but so far they have been a success to everyone.Overall I would say 8.3.2.0.7/10 if I were a critic, however I'm not one so really that personal score is irrelevant. You should decide whether or not you enjoy the game yourself and buy it :)The people behind SE and now ME need to be hugged for making both games and if you enjoy this game buy Space Engineers or vice versa!It's worth it.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								I just played medieval engineers, and decided to write this review even though I played only few houres in the game.The game is amazing . Here are some good and bad points that I think it is importent to give them a try  : Good:1) demolition amazing animation and fun. (There is nothing more fun than destroying stuff you built).2) stunning graphics.3) the possible construction areas, which require creativity and great design (because the laws of physics can be found in the game, not just so building, which adds a challenge and fun).Bad:1) The game takes a long time to to be loaded.2) The ground editor very uncomfortable, and very unfriendly to new players.3) The voice of the barbarians annoying .. would be great if it would be possible to change the sound or mute the barbarians in particular.To improve:I noticed a couple of things I would love if repaired or will be added to the game.1)I think it would be great if you feel the possibility of Ctrl + Z so that we can correct mistakes we made.2) I think that could be great if the world would be added flat type, so that it can be built on a flat surface without shape the surface of the earth.3) Would be great if added to the tool which can erase the ruins. It's quite annoying that you can not delete ruins and each time build a castle tower and he falls to start the game again and build it all again. (I must say that it makes the construction of a castle feel pretty stressful thing).In conclusion, a great game. The game can provide hours and hours of building castles and weapons medieval building demolition, careful planning of buildings.Would be great if he could contain multiplayer game, or at least co-op so that it can be done wars or joint construction (similar to space engineers).Highly recommanded , Buy it now !! 11 \ 10!*by the way  , I apologize for my poor English . Thank you for reading my review :D

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								**Update ReviewI don't bother with the custom maps anymore.. It is a lot less buggy but still has it's issues, The AI are not as stupid but they are still very very dumb. Building is extremely difficult; you have to look at a block in the just the right way to place it properly for structural integrity and annoying enough to make you want to give up on the game altogether. I have a mid level system and I don't notice any lag issues anymore when i play a built in map with less physics and such. I can't review the servers or multiplayer because there are just never any people online to test it out with. It's showing more potential but the building aspect needs improvement as well as more bug fixes and AI definitely needs improvement. If you have the patience to play; it's so very confusing figuring things out. content:
Posted: April 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Medieval Engineers has very high potential it is hard to criticise it as it is early access however I will say what I can.I simply cannot recommend this game at its current state, it has too many bugs and issues the worst of all is the optimisation of this game is not finished they simply need to tinker and polish a few things and BAM it would be good.I have a decent rig (if you want to know the specs just ask) that is well above recommended settings yet I get at best 7fps... yep thats 7fps it's practically unplayable.The actual game itself will be good in a couple of years when the full versions out and updates upon updates are coming out it could be the next Minecraft, until the developers finish Space Engineers FULLY is when this game will truly shine.KIMBOF1's Score = 2/5The game itself isn't very good and on top of that is a mountain of bugs and issues.Think before you play over 2 hours of this game I tried to get a refund but the Steam Refund Policy states that to get a refund you must have owned the game for under 2 weeks and played it for under 2 hours.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a reskinned Space Engineers, no doubt about it. But I'm honestly impressed. In just an hour of play I can tell you this game is worth $15. The textures are strikingly beautiful, the building is currently decent with much room for growth, and you can tell that this game will get to be pretty all-around excellent with a bit of love and a lot of added content. Your current options as of now are to build and destroy--and the latter is pretty damn fun. You have no way of actually repairing things yet, like you can in SE. Physics is excellent; object destruction appears very real. I'm interested in seeing mining, refining, and other SE-type properties imported medieval-style.

Early Access Review
								Boy do i love this game,in fact its a serious game,i appreciate every  moment in this very pleasant and inspiring environment. Wow am i excited about the potential Medieval Engineers has, as well done as Space Engineers .i love the calm Medieval music and also the special  effects that no other games i`ve seen yet have .This is a large step for Man ! and maybe a turning point in simulation gaming . GG Guys!

number of helpful: 30 of 61 people (49%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								From the moment that I saw this game in a Youtube video I know that I had to play it.The first few minutes:After the installation I was quickly confronted with the complexity of this game. Since there is no good tutorial (just annoying text in the middle of the screen) I immediately was forced to watch multiple "How to play" video's to get started. I personally do not mind this but I can imagine that other people might find this annoying.Building:The complexity of the Keybindings, moving around and placing blocks are in my opinion too difficult. The way that building blocks can be selected, rotated and placed is just not smooth enough. It somehow feels slow and not efficient, I am sure that this can be improved. The 3rd person camera angle in this game is one of the most annoying elements of this game. Although I would have liked to use this camera angle, it was just too buggy for my. The camera keeps jumping around and is just too unpredictable which made me feel nauseous.Gameplay:This is a big let down for me. I knew that this was going to be a building game, but at this state there is no gameplay at all. Yes there is multiplayer and some form of enemy AI, but in the end it is just a set of tools that allows the user of this software to create a 3D environment. Therefore, this piece of software should not be promoted as a game when it is just a digital toy.Visuals & audio:This game does look quite good and features a nice art style. The music and audio fit the software well and gives the user an emerging experience.HUD, UI & menu:The menu of the game is clear and easy to understand. The videos in the background look nice and gives a good impression of the features that this software has. The UI and HUD look quite basic and could use some improvements.Multiplayer:I have spent some time on a server, building my little castle in survival mode together with other players it was quite fun.  But again, the lack of gameplay made it boring after a while. I also noticed that there are almost no players on multiplayer, I was expecting servers full of players but in reality there are just about 5 to 10 players playing this online. Overall experience:Building a castle, bridge or other building is fun but becomes boring after a short while. After making some random buildings, a bridge, and some castles I feel bored. The lack of gameplay reduces replayability of this game and does not challenge the player to keep playing. Conclusion:Maybe it is not my type of "game", but it was quite a let down for me. The game is hard to get into, then becomes fun but then quickly becomes boring. I hope that I gave enough feedback to improve this game in the future.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								Being co-developed at the same time as Space Engineers, one would think the premise would work in medeival times as also, but it just doesn't. Many features are still missing, which is okay because it is still in development, but the real issue is with the interface. It was bad in Space Engineers, but workable. In this, it just doesn't work (at least not with flying turned off.) Building up requires getting pretty creative with scaffolding type parts or jumping between blocks (don't fall off or you will be stuck trying to cobble together some type of stairway.) Once resource requirements are implemented, this is going to be a real issue. Figuring out how all the parts work together is interesting, challenging, and frankly downright frustrating sometimes, again due to the shoddy interface. The game looks beautiful at least.I would love to recommend this title as I really enjoy the idea of being able to build freely, but with the clunky interface and the current lack of working features, I just can't recommend it at this time. Maybe in the future it will be a different story.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Although this game is pretty entertaining, I wouldn't buy it right now. You should wait until the creators add real survival to the game. Right now, survival is just creative, except you can die, can't fly, and can't spawn in bots or use voxel tools. Already, there are griefers in this game. All they have to do is throw a huge stone at your base and it crumbles. You don't even have to build weapons to grief. All you have to do is equip a stone and click to throw. Next, the tools, as of now, are very basic. For some reason, I've been able to mine with an axe. I can still mine with a pickaxe, but how int he world do you mine with an axe?! On a more serious note, the bots are terrible. You'll see barbarians that run to a king's statue, hit it, then run away. Then, they come back a minute later and finish off the statue. Also, miners accidently kill each other while they mine. Since you can't pick up rocks, the stone you get from mining just lags your game. Anyway, that's my sort of negative review. Oh, one last thing. The building mechanic are pretty terrible. I remember building a stone column a few blocks high. Somehow, a wooden platform broke it. How the HECK does wood destroy stone?! You know what's weird? I just talked about a billion negatives and I still recommend the game. Eh, I'm too lazy to write the positives.

content:

Early Access Review
								I find this game to be absolutely amazing! And I know that a lot of people are complaining that it is abandoned, but it isn't! They give regular update videos every Tuesday. They are working through developing new ideas and introducing them is going to take awhile. They can't give huge updates whilst working on them at the same time. Maybe if they had 50 programmers working on the project, they could. They are a smaller company and cannot add huge updates every week or even every month. This game continues to have great potential and we all just need to be more patient so that the programmers have the time they need to bring their ideas to fruition.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								Medieval Engineers is a great sandbox voxel-based builder in concept, but still has many issues because it is in early access.  The main places where it falls short are Survival mode and optimization.  The Survival mode has just barely been implemented, and is... well just bad for now, but that will probably be fixed very soon as the devs are pretty active.  But the main thing that bothers me is that most computers can't even run this game yet.  I have a $300 gaming computer with a 6-core processor and 16 gigs of RAM that can run Portal 2 smoothly on max graphics, and I can only run this game at about 5 fps on the lowest settings.  I wish I could rate a "kind of" for do you recommend this game.  If you have an amazing computer that can run this game smoothly, then I would definitely say to get Medieval Engineers, but if not I would wait and see if they improve how the game runs first.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game has been in "Early Access" for an eternity. I bought it early hoping I could support it and make it better, but it's never come even close to being a decent playable game:- Poorly optimized. Crashes often on a pretty good computer, and even when it doesn't crash it's super laggy.- Glitchy. Character often gets stuck at random spots. Even in the pre-set environments, like the pre-loaded castle, there are tons of spots where you just randomly can't move.- Interaction with objects is fairly useless. Again, even in the pre-set environments, the objects like catapults and drawbridges are purely for show.- Gravity is useless. There are no calculations for structural integrity, so you might as well play Minecraft.- Build tools are very rudimentary. Again, even Minecraft has more variety than this, and is a playable game to boot.- Graphics suck. There are no other skins or textures in the base game, much less an ability to choose between them in the same castle. Everything starts to look the same after a while.If you want to design and "build" castles, just use Google Sketchup. If you want to play in a fortress of your design, play Minecraft or any of the dozens of other games out there in the same vein. This one just felt like a giant waste of time and money.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is basically minecraft in permanent creative mode applied to building a sand castle for you to kick down later. You just spawn things in. Eventually Barbarians come and knock it down. You build again elsewhere. In multiplayer you just build something and watch as someone knocks it down. There is nothing alive in the world. You don't mine for resources, harvest trees, nothing. Just you spawning in pre-designed blocks and pieces of a castle to build your own castle. Same map every time, same castle, same design. I just don't get this "game". There isn't anything here. The physics is very complex and realistic, and clearly an ernormous volume of work has been put into this. But it isn't a game. It isn't even any sort of sim. There isn't any point to this at all unless you like kicking over sand castles in a permanent "god mode" with unlimited everything.This game has been in early access for a long time now, and I do receive updates for it from time to time. However I am yet to see anything change at all in the game. Starting to feel like a dead game that isn't even 10% complete to me, or was it always intended to be nothing else than a very bad "medieval garry's mod"?

content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								I bought this along with space engineers some time ago. My computer couldn't run them at the time, so I held off. Even though I barely made the minimum requirements for SE, it was 5 eye-bleeding-FPS. But now, even with my 8GB RAM and 3.9ghz 6-core, it takes some minimal settings. (so yeah, even a Radeon 6570 can struggle through).Anyway, I've had some time to see it change, and it only gets progressively better. Some people think the recent update is a step backward. Thruthfully, it's a step sideways (little was removed, but a lot of quality-of-living things have been improved).  It's getting there. Give it some time.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Honestly, i was excited when i hear about it, but since its been out, ive been addicted, even with the little content block wise and workshop items, creations are endless, Now we can create any medieval RPG in whatever way we want, for as long and as big as we want. This game is a Masterpiece,.::: July Update :::...... Yup, still as awesome as it was before, it just got even better!.::: September Update :::.I still cant find anything i agree with in this game,i have especially enjoyed some of the little sneak previews the developers, have either intentionally left into the game for us to find, or just by accident, but from these we can see just how much detail is going to get put into the game. So far i have sumbled upon a number of unique player Skins, which include:Female Engineer ModelsChildren Player /NPC Models"Old Man" Player /NPC ModelAnd new forms of hostile animals to be introduced into the world including the "Medieval Wolf"Ive found all of these inside the Small chest ingame while using Creative, and after every update i now lov to go and check it out incase there's something new in there which could possibly tell us whats coming next. With previews like this it leaves the door open for more things to be created such as: Plate Armour, Chain-mail. Leather armour, Warhammers, Maces and Fails, it is essentially endless, and with the annoucement of "Brain AI" this could protentally become of the most advanced Player NPC Interaction game out there.As for the building, its only got better and more stable as its progressed, and now through their weeks up bugfixing the game is getting even smoother, ive seen this personally with a few friends who wern't able to run the game very well before and now they can. I've even started my own projects such as building a re-creation of the Runescape World across several maps. I can only hope that one day the developers will bring out large maps one day which will allow players to build kingdoms together through continous generation.This is the only review i enjoy updating if im completely honest and i will update it again in the future!

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								I purchased space engineers had more than the requirements to run the game but was terribly disappointed when i did. Despite having a fairly good system the game itself is a lag monster of epic proportions. Sadly...it found its way into the delete bin. Fast forward to Medieval Engineers. I threw caution to the wind and read all the reviews and figured what the hell give the devs one more try and see if this game fared any better than space engineers. Well to be honest in fact its worse. The game lags terribly even at the lowest setting. The AI is horrific and the game lacks lustre in general. I realize this is early release and i hate to sound so overwhelmingly negative but in my humble opinion i really think the devs need to get into a different line of work. It seems like the only thing theyre concentrating on is your dollar. One more title for the delete bin.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is everything I wanted from 'Minecraft' but couldn't get.  At the moment I'm engaged in the Castle building rather than the machine construction.  I can see the potential for future pieces and blocks - and once the modding community gets going the buildings will be fabulous (rather than just great).The placing of blocks can be a struggle sometimes and even with update .008 the lighting is a real pain.  It's as if the devs are trying to be too clever by putting in day/night, sun position etc before fixing the awful shadow problems.  The interior lighting still needs a lot of work.However, it is still early access and apart from the lighting problems this game is well on the way to getting 5 stars and being my favourite.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Owned Space Engineers and played it for quite a bit and so far I like what I see in Medieval Engineers. It has several useful mechanics that we will hopefully see implemented into Space Engineers but also has a few things that need to be addressed, that one would of thought wouldn't be a problem.Let's start off simple:Medieval Engineers is a branch off of Space Engineers developed by an entirely seperate team within the same studio so that both games can continue to grow and be improved without splitting the time and effort between one game or the other. This is an exceptionally good thing because it means we won't have to deal with prolonged update times or glitches having to be put on hold as they alternate. Another good thing from this is that as one development team comes up with a great concept within their own, it will then eventually be transplanted into the other essentially improving both games at the same time, a double bonus for us who own both.I enjoy the fact it is a lot easier to place blocks within the same tile now so that you can easily fix wall placement and/or fortifications that would otherwise have some very weird looking repairs/modifications to themselves and it also allows you to merge blocks that would normally not have been placed together to create even more interesting designs. Since this game released roughly a little over a month ago now, it is already impressive.The implementation of the structural integrity build adds much to the "Engineering" aspect of this game which many had claimed had been missing from Space Engineers. Sure we get to build things, but they aren't always sound nor well thought out and now we're forced to do both. We experiment and build a design and then when it falls apart, we take it apart and see what went wrong so we can fix it or build it even better the next time. When it comes to designing structures and defenses, this is a great mechanic at seeing what is already weak and needs to be reinforced instead of having to destroy it first. However, this mechanic is still very much a prototype of the final feature. There are bugs with this and as it is only in Alpha Stage so far even with the public release. Where one time it can function properly, other times things will fall apart even when they're sound. It can be annoying but then this is an Alpha, don't expect everything to be working properly.Many people complain the price of the game at $19.99 or $14.99 USD for those who already own Space Engineers is a bit much. For those just coming in, I can see why you would think that as there have been many cash grabs in the past but these developers have already been around for over a year with Space Engineers and it has come a remarkably long way. With the quality, care, and dedication they've put in their other version, I would easily pay more for this kind of game even though it's far from release because they keep re-polishing it, the workshop is a major source of custom mods and/or net-code UI, and better yet, it fits my favorite time frame of the Medieval Period in general.Multiplayer hasn't been fully implemented yet but then in Space Engineers, it took over four months for that to come out and when it did, it was working with very few bugs and overall was very enjoyable. It gave people time to experiment and plan ahead on what worked and what didn't so that way when you and your friends decide to have a battle-royale, you could make it work the way you imagined it (maybe, depends on your creativity).Overall, with just a few minutes of gameplay experimenting with the new features, I can safely say that this game has brought several much needed changes to the table and can only get better from here on out. (Knock on wood, don't want to jinx the unimaginable happening).Overall Score: 9.1/10The game is in Alpha mode so I respect that there are still some bugs/features that don't work properly but overall, the game has a steady framerate, the destruction engine doesn't lag as much as it used to, better building interface and UI, somewhat functioning AI which is a great hint at what is to come.For those of you who don't already own it, I suggest also getting Space Engineers. For tips, help, and general improvements to those starting out, try watching some videoes from LastStandGamers. They're a tremendous help to the community and also take out shoutouts for things people want to try but can't build on their own yet.https://www.youtube.com/user/LastStandGamers

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is everything I wanted from 'Minecraft' but couldn't get.  At the moment I'm engaged in the Castle building rather than the machine construction.  I can see the potential for future pieces and blocks - and once the modding community gets going the buildings will be fabulous (rather than just great).The placing of blocks can be a struggle sometimes and even with update .008 the lighting is a real pain.  It's as if the devs are trying to be too clever by putting in day/night, sun position etc before fixing the awful shadow problems.  The interior lighting still needs a lot of work.However, it is still early access and apart from the lighting problems this game is well on the way to getting 5 stars and being my favourite.

Early Access Review
								Owned Space Engineers and played it for quite a bit and so far I like what I see in Medieval Engineers. It has several useful mechanics that we will hopefully see implemented into Space Engineers but also has a few things that need to be addressed, that one would of thought wouldn't be a problem.Let's start off simple:Medieval Engineers is a branch off of Space Engineers developed by an entirely seperate team within the same studio so that both games can continue to grow and be improved without splitting the time and effort between one game or the other. This is an exceptionally good thing because it means we won't have to deal with prolonged update times or glitches having to be put on hold as they alternate. Another good thing from this is that as one development team comes up with a great concept within their own, it will then eventually be transplanted into the other essentially improving both games at the same time, a double bonus for us who own both.I enjoy the fact it is a lot easier to place blocks within the same tile now so that you can easily fix wall placement and/or fortifications that would otherwise have some very weird looking repairs/modifications to themselves and it also allows you to merge blocks that would normally not have been placed together to create even more interesting designs. Since this game released roughly a little over a month ago now, it is already impressive.The implementation of the structural integrity build adds much to the "Engineering" aspect of this game which many had claimed had been missing from Space Engineers. Sure we get to build things, but they aren't always sound nor well thought out and now we're forced to do both. We experiment and build a design and then when it falls apart, we take it apart and see what went wrong so we can fix it or build it even better the next time. When it comes to designing structures and defenses, this is a great mechanic at seeing what is already weak and needs to be reinforced instead of having to destroy it first. However, this mechanic is still very much a prototype of the final feature. There are bugs with this and as it is only in Alpha Stage so far even with the public release. Where one time it can function properly, other times things will fall apart even when they're sound. It can be annoying but then this is an Alpha, don't expect everything to be working properly.Many people complain the price of the game at $19.99 or $14.99 USD for those who already own Space Engineers is a bit much. For those just coming in, I can see why you would think that as there have been many cash grabs in the past but these developers have already been around for over a year with Space Engineers and it has come a remarkably long way. With the quality, care, and dedication they've put in their other version, I would easily pay more for this kind of game even though it's far from release because they keep re-polishing it, the workshop is a major source of custom mods and/or net-code UI, and better yet, it fits my favorite time frame of the Medieval Period in general.Multiplayer hasn't been fully implemented yet but then in Space Engineers, it took over four months for that to come out and when it did, it was working with very few bugs and overall was very enjoyable. It gave people time to experiment and plan ahead on what worked and what didn't so that way when you and your friends decide to have a battle-royale, you could make it work the way you imagined it (maybe, depends on your creativity).Overall, with just a few minutes of gameplay experimenting with the new features, I can safely say that this game has brought several much needed changes to the table and can only get better from here on out. (Knock on wood, don't want to jinx the unimaginable happening).Overall Score: 9.1/10The game is in Alpha mode so I respect that there are still some bugs/features that don't work properly but overall, the game has a steady framerate, the destruction engine doesn't lag as much as it used to, better building interface and UI, somewhat functioning AI which is a great hint at what is to come.For those of you who don't already own it, I suggest also getting Space Engineers. For tips, help, and general improvements to those starting out, try watching some videoes from LastStandGamers. They're a tremendous help to the community and also take out shoutouts for things people want to try but can't build on their own yet.https://www.youtube.com/user/LastStandGamers

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								The game has a lot of potential but i couldnt really enjoy it. Its not user friendly (lol) i had a hard time remembering what did what to get it to snap and it was more frustrating playing then fun for me. Maybe if they idk how but fix that i would consider playing it more.  Like i said the game has a lot of potential to go far but could definatly be tweaked to make for a more fun "Medieval" Game play experience.  I know its still relitively new but like i said it was mostly just frustrating for me than fun. I know there are a lot of people who have played it and fallen in love with it. This is just my personal experience and opinion of the game.  Once you get the hang of what you're doing its not so bad, but it felt more of a chore because there was just so much going on and so much i had to do to place down a simple block that it just wasnt enjoyable for me. Which is disapointing because i was really excited to play. It reminded me of a medieval minecraft and unfortunately i went into it expecting it to be similar to minecraft in that way and it just really wasnt. Which might be why I had such a difficult time. There were a lot of things in the game that were very janky, and just couldnt be done no matter how much i pressed E R T Y.  I would have to say that i didnt care much for it but i do recomend it because its the type of game you have to play yourself to see if you enjoy it.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Chopped down a tree,Tree fell and squished me.I spawn picking up logs,Made a house.Got more wood, tree fell on me again.Captures logs as prisonors for future use.Defently will get squashed by tree again.Ok seriously now. People are reviewing this as if its a full release which its an Early Release so yes theres a few bugs and glitches which does not break the game apart from the one time  I fell through the world which never happened again and was fixed with a quick load.When I started I decided to go into creative and build to see what happens when I go from being releastic to unreleastic to see how far I can go until physicics come into place, once I understood how that works in this game I went into survival.Survival is very basic for now. Health Bar, Food Bar and Stamina bar. You start with a tempary cart which despawns when you leave the game but  you can use the parts and keep them. It has basic parts like a bed weapons, tools and other items.  I chopped down trees, found out what I needed to build the foundation of my house, slowly i was building walls, floors and a roof.   It took me a while to learn what type of wood I need but in no time I have a roof over my head.I was able to cook on a campfire for food, hunt Deer and pick mushrooms.  But only having a game play of 9,1hours from writing this I do see potential and I am looking forward for updates towards survival.My pc is a mid range, new pc from 2009, updated motherboard and Graphics only.Pros: Lovely sceneary         The ablilty to go online with friends and play.          Survival mode           Watching a tree create a dominos effect. (I crushed my house once)           Creative mode            Able to build anything you can think of            Watching things crumble is amazing.           Simple controls and Space Engineers (same company i know) will be fine with  them.           able to hunt animals and attack defend from barberians.Cons: Not enough wild aniamls.          smaller trees sometimes flick out and kills you for no reason but fix to be done.          Not enough friendly NPCs or villages apart from what you make or a world you spawn that has them.

Early Access Review
								I have not played this game a whole lot but i really like the way they are going. I see a lot of role play possibilities with the kingdom mechanic. I think the crafting is well made and its not overly complicated, i do however would prefer a more minecraft ish crafting mechanic and display, kind of feels like there are a few more steps then needed to craft. They have been doing a great job with implementing the voxels to fit together.Would love to see water (Rivers, Lakes and Oceans) and fishing, with a in depth mechanic to farming. Would also like to eventually see pre made towns with AI's wandering around doing their daily things etc.I would recommend this game to others, it has a lot in it considering they have been putting a lot of time into Space Engineers. Even more fun to play with friends.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								The System Requirements are insanely high (significantly higher than even GTA 5) and are deliberately not highlighted before you actually purchase the game. Check http://www.medievalengineers.com/system-requirements.html to ensure you can actually run the game before buying it. If you don't meet the minimum requirements the game will give you an error message and refuse to launch. TLDR: GFX cards > 1 year old will struggle, > 2 years won't launch at all.I was able to run Space Engineers (which imo is a better looking game too) on full settings with no problems whatsoever.Checking the forums shows other people having similar issues as well as endless stability issues.Far and away the least finished early access game I've ever seen - they clearly released after a couple of months just to cash in on the early money off the back of some fairly promising looking trailers.STEER WELL CLEAR.

number of helpful: 21 of 44 people (48%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
Early Access Review
***DON'T BUY THIS IF YOU'RE ON WINDOWS 10 AND HAVE AN NVIDIA BASED GRAPHICS CARD.***I would love to write a positive review of this game... But I can't. I wouldn't be posting a technical issue as a poor review, BUT this particular bug has been around for over a month at least, and the work around involving Windows 10 and nVidia graphics card drivers (that's not really posted or documented well) is to DOWNGRADE your drivers to a specific range. This bug does not affect the game's sister product, Space Engineers, so I'm scratching my head at this one.I will change this review IF AND WHEN they address the graphics problems for nVidia cards.

number of helpful: 17 of 36 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								With survival and multiplayer released and after 3 months of further development - is it worth buying now?Graphics:The graphics are quite good for being made from scratch and the optimisation is better than expected. The physics/destructible blocks are well done, only from time to time they behave rather wonky. All in all a visually pleasing experience.Audio:The music of the game is really fantastic and underlines the medieval setting. Other sounds often don't work or are not appropiate - may be placeholders though?!Gameplay:The construction system brings some needed innovation with it and mostly works better than it's space counterpart (Space Engineers). Those blocks that are available are nicely done, however there are so few of them even months after release.Content:Multiplayer seems to be the same as in Space Engineers and fulfills it's purpose. Survival however is nothing more than Creative without flying and god-mode - I really don't understand why they didn't copy the code from Space Engineers so the players at least have an inventory and can gather resources. (It seems an inventory system will be introduced later on, logs/stones have to be transported manually)To sum it up:After 3 months with a (for an early access) big development team one would think that many of the flaws that plagued the release version would have been fixed by now. Unfortunately the game is still glorified lego without much content. This is why I can't recommend buying the game in it's current state especially with this price tag.P.S. Just compare it to minecraft alpha which could be bought for less than 10€ and had much more content (finished suvival/creative/multiplayer and extensive crafting/inventory system)

content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								This really isn't a game....Putting a piece of software available to purchase in the state this game is in, is just wrong.I'm a professional developer of 20+ years and there just ins't any excuse for this.OK, so you can build stuff...  beyond that though, that's it.I've played quite a few "early access" games, which all of had actual "content" to them upon inital release.  THis game doesn't.Pros.- You can build pretty cool looking stuff.- There are barbarians.Cons.- Building is quite frustrating as the snapping is very bad.  Takes a LOT of very steady mouse movement.- Terrian editing needs a LOT of work.  A LOT!- Barbarians don't seem to do anything but run around sideways and backwards.Not worth trying to mention all this game has or doesn't as it only has like 1 or 2 features.  Besides, most people are just going to flag this thumbs down - not helpful.Here's the helpful part of this review.  If you like Minecraft, you will probably like this game... Don't expect more from this than to build stuff, and knock it down, and start over.  If you're good with this, this might give you entertainment.I would like, and recommend this game if the building was more intuative.  But as it stands, it needs a LOT of work, which means, the game is too early to release and ask for $$$$.If the game interests you, flag it as watching and come back in 6 months.  I do not recomment spending money on this right now.It has a lot of potential...  just none of it has been implemented - yet.

number of helpful: 10 of 22 people (45%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								2016 EDIT BELOWI bought this game under the assumption that all of the features in the announcement video would be taken care of in a month or two after launch. These features are still missing as the game has a constant flow of small updates that are generally useless towards gameplay.If you wanted this game to build medieval contraptions, with and without the mechanical blocks shown in the announcement video, don't buy this. Wait eight or nine months until the game is actually updated with these features so there are things to do.The current contraptions you can build without mechanical blocks are usually buggy/broken and tend to explode and collide for no reason. The devs generally base the updates around what a certain SE/ME community that I won't name, but honestly it's pretty sad because this game could have been a lot better at this stage if the devs actually based updates around core gameplay, but instead they don't even mention the issues people have with the game.Space Engineers is great (Slightly lacking singleplayer content aside) and I would 100% recommend buying it, but please: don't buy Medieval Engineers. I regret purchasing my pre-release version a lot.EDIT-------------------------Its now february 2016, not one set of blocks, mechanical or otherwise has been added to the game since my original review. The developers have completely decided to ignore the mechanical aspects of this game shown in trailer and to early reviewers. The devs have done virtually nothing in the past 10 months to add to this game, and despite showing us the game's "Roadmap" not a single thing from even it has been implemented into the game. The weekly updates are a literal joke, and keen seems to have diverted very very little resources to this game despite them saying the contrary.Supposedly survival is being worked on right now, but the game undoubtedly seems to be in development hell. Survival will have no purpose when there aren't any other finished features in the game. The dev's working on this have started work on multiple core features and completely abandoned them after a single update.This game is a huge dissapointment, it's horribly misadvertised and I think KSH should be ashamed to falsely represent a game like this, whilst at the same time lying about development progress expectations.Please don't buy this game.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is GOOD but i have no i ♥♥♥♥ing dear what the developers are thinking and because of that i give this game a NO (for now because of the following).This game is literally unplayable due to the lag... I can't believe someone would even release a game that is as laggy as this is, i have never experienced so much lag in my life. Before people start pointing the finger at my computer or internet ill stop you right there, it is not my internet or computer so delete that from your equation.If anything on the map is destroyed by a catapult or one of the many griefers decide to throw cannon balls at your creation you wont be able to build for around 5 minutes due to the fragmented destruction of objects...If you build a catapult and winch the shaft back with a rope connected to the rope drum DO NOT BUILD A SINGLE THING ON THAT CATAPULT WHILST IT IS CONNECTED TO THE ROPE DRUM!! The entire catapult will explode even if you build one 1x1 piece of wood onto it.... this is extremely frustrating and once again i have no idea what the hell the developers are doing not fixing that... When using a hook on the end of the catapult shaft to launch cannon balls you cant change the angle that much of where you want the cannon ball to be thrown. If you angle it too far left or right the ball just doesn't release and ends up swinging out of control on the end of the shaft then after 10 seconds the cannon ball releases off the hook and then lands on your catapult more than likely destroying it.. so stupid..The stone objects crumble too easily.. take out the front of a castle and the entire thing will collapse because the stability is extremely broken in this game.GRIEFERS oh my♥♥♥♥♥♥♥god!! This game is just full of people who run up to what ever you are making and just decide to destroy it for no reason.. it is literally impossible to make anything that lasts longer than 5 minutes. That's why you see people building on the side of mountains high up to get away from these♥♥♥♥♥♥♥moronic people. Takes 1 swing of a hammer to destroy anything... and soon as you destroy 1 piece of anything it fks the entire object up..What i want to see fixed are the following.-Anti grief-Fall damage is way too sensitive..-Fix the god damn unplayable lag-Fix stability-Make a vote kick system-Fix the voxel (think they are called voxel?) objects, they are an absolute mess (the textures)-Fix ropes-Fix the rope drum sensitivity when winding it up or down, trying to turn a catapult on a rotor to position the aim is     impossible due to the sensitivity of the pull-Fix building on a catapult that is loaded and ready to fire (explodes/breaks)-Fix the release options of hooks used to swing cannon balls (pressing K brings up this menu)-Fix wheels-Fix the strength of stone objects-Fix the strength of melee weapons-Make more creative type servers-Take away the option to be able to throw cannon balls at 100kmph at peoples bases in creative.. seriously wtf..-You should only be able to destroy someone base if the projectile comes from a catapult or something that has thrown   the projectile.. not your friggin hands-Once again, the unplayable lag needs to be fixed..

content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								Yes, you can make pretty functional machinery with wood and rope and throw stones out of view.The whole movement system is really bad, within 30 minutes of playing I get so fed up with the mouse look / movement action and not to mention the tiny rope connect points. The default siege scenario castles are poorly put together and cramped. A pit in the middle with a walk the plank escape route is hardly a feature one likes to contend with while attempting to strafe around an over sized battlement catapult to attach a rope simply because the range is just to far from my player. The Devs need to tune in the realism at a later date when the rest of the game is more functional. For now it's too cumbersome to have any fun. Don't buy it just yet. KHS should suspend the AI project and keep the cash flow pouring into SE and ME as the weekly updates are not what people are requesting and seem to be predetermined and bottle-necked.This game does have great scope and I hope a real future. We should all be a little more patient when it comes to good things :)

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game barely got my Yes vote, on the sole realization that it is still Early Access. I plan to re-review it whenever the quirks I note are fixed.This game has a nice building system that is held back from an awful physics system. You can build a vehicle out of a thousand pounds of material, and accidentally walk into it to send it flying across the field. This was an awkward system that we didn't see in space engineers.Creation of true siege equipment like battering rams and trebuchets are limited to only being visually appealing, rather than actually functional. Even with "tearable rope", trebuchets are wonky, at best. Battering rams filled with steel "weights" can't bust through a single layer of timber (But remember, your average-sized body can toss the battering ram across the field, if it has wheels)This game has a lot of potential, but right now, it really can't harness my creative mind nearly as well as space engineers, and with good reason, space engineers has had much longer to develop. I hope developers will address the wonky physics system in future updates.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game has a great deal of potential.   However, at this time I cannot recommend buying it.  In a year or two it's probably gong to be great, but I'm looking for a game I can play NOW.  I love Space Engineers and have almost 600 hours on it, but I bought it after it was 18 to 24 months into development and the survival mode was actually playable.  At this time survival mode is really just Creative mode with a different label.  You still place an infinite number of blocks without needing any materials and there are no recipes to craft any of the blocks yet, even if you have materials.  I really wish I had been able to tell this before buying it, but real hard information on gameplay is hard to come by. As I said, in a year or two this might be a fantastic game, but for right now it's just a 3d building/modeling program, not really a game.

								So a long- long time ago it was a very cute little game about castle building - I've spent a good total of over 100 hours tinkering with keeps ,sities and mines, and it was a lot of fun although it was lacking a lot of parts and wasn't spacialy big ,but now the game is entirely new - giant world's , a work- in -progress RPG system (R.I.P. castle siege ,didn't need you anyway) and most importantly - that feeling of Terra-nova that space engienrs acomplished in 2015. BUt honestly - it's already great , so why not to play it?

content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Ok, it is never easy to write a good Early Access Review. The basic rule is to review the game features. not the bugs, because these should be squashed sometime during the alpha and beta test phase. but Ok here we go.The game has a sandbox and a survival mode. in sandbox, it is basically build for free, your character can fly, great for the creative mind and for learning the basic mechanics of the game.In survial mode, your character needs to eat to stay alive. food can be found in the form of berries, muchrooms and you can hunt game for a nice chop of deer meat. Jummie.Besides starvation, the other ways of dying are being crushed by a falling tree or any other heavy object, killed by other players or AI (PvPvE). There is an option to play off-line and without barbarian bits as well if you don't like that aspect.To build your castle in survival is a very rewarding but time consuming process. for example a single foundation block takes 20 stone and 10 wood chips to build. you can carry 10 wood chips fine, but only 1 stone. It would take for ever to build a castle without some form of transport.This is where the engineering bit really comes to life. I started really enjoying the game after building my first cart that is pulled up the hill using a drum and rope. after chopping down some trees or gathering stone in the quarry, I simply fill the boxes on my cart, go back to the scaffolding site and haul the cart in with the rope spindle.If you are up to being clever enough to build things like this, or cranes or other medieval construction mechanics, this game is for you!Also, every now and then save your game under a different name. build a Trebuchet or catapult and demolish your work. Big fun, then load your backup save game and continue building. Remarks: Make sure you have a decent computer! my I7 laptop with GeForce GT 630M can barely run the game. Also I had to downgrade my graphics drivers to Nvidia driver version 355.98 because of a lightning error that occurs with later drivers. Performance improvements are normally done in a later development phase, but until than the game has heavy physics and graphics demands.Another thing is the learning curve. There are many tutorials on the web, but due to the many updates these are out of date quickly and some times they are not representing the latest version of the game any more. It often takes a lot of efford and asking on the forums how a new feature works. Again, tutorials and hints are normally implemented in the final stages of game development.For an early acces game, It is at the moment already very playable en enjoyable and it has all the potential to become a great game once finished. Therefore the game has my recommendation!

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								The rule is easy: if you're not into medieval castles and simple (but creative as hell) engineering, this game isn't for you.But if you like to build castles, houses, towns, in for purpose minecraft, but never destroyed them with projectiles and a self-made catapult and felt ashamed of it, you want this game.If you like building stuff on survival with fair difficulity, you want this game.If you love medieval era, you want this game.Want a trebuchet? Balista? Siege tower? You can make it in this game. And experience the glorious and often funny bugs with physics when shooting a deer.Like engineering gates, moving bridges, whole clock mechanisms? - you want to play this game.Ever wanted to make a stronghold block-by-block? You want this game.Loved the stronghold series? You want this game.If you just like building things, you want this game.Game works pretty good, but it's obvious that with a 2500+ blocks it wont run fast and smooth.Loved space engineers, but want a more "traditional" experience? Play it. It's great.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								With the understanding that it's early access (I dislike how often the steam community needs to be reminded of this), I certainly recommend this game.  The physics and destruction technologies are astounding, and worth the price just by themselves in my opinion.That being said, I usually spend most of my time building contraptions or weapons, and less frequently have I engaged in survival gameplay or multiplayer.  Survival does not yet feel finished, but I think it's headed in the right direction.  The multiplayer that I have engaged in doesn't seem to have any glaring problems.But I feel that where this game really shines is when you come up with some crazy new idea for a weapon or portcullis or something, build it, and it actually WORKS more or less like you expect it to.  That's rare for a physics engine.I built an extendible bridge the other day that opens with a scissor-like motion, all just by turning a crank.  And it actually worked!  I've read some complaints that it's hard to put stuff together, so I guess there might be a learning curve.  Personally, I thought it was pretty intuitive and well designed.  The controls to rotate blocks could be better, though.As far as performance issues go, I have a $1500 rig, which I feel is a sort of upper-middle-range price (not ludicrous, certainly).  I play on pretty much maxed-out settings at 2560x1440 and I don't usually see the fps drop below 80.  It hasn't been a problem for me.  I agree that it isn't very optimized yet, though, so if you've got an older or budget build at the moment then the time might not be right to buy.  Also, my build is Intel/Nvidia based, and I don't know how much that affects this game (there was some question about that in other reviews).Anyway, building contraptions (not to mention castles) makes me happy, so if you're anything like me, you ought to like this game.  And I'm very impressed with what they've accomplished with Space Engineers, so I'm pretty excited about what Medieval Engineers will become.  It's kept up a pretty good development pace so far.TL;DR:Survival and other aspects are unfinished, but the physics-based engineering/inventing dynamic even just in creative mode makes this game worth the price. [LAST REMINDER - THIS GAME IS EARLY ACCESS]

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								The rule is easy: if you're not into medieval castles and simple (but creative as hell) engineering, this game isn't for you.But if you like to build castles, houses, towns, in for purpose minecraft, but never destroyed them with projectiles and a self-made catapult and felt ashamed of it, you want this game.If you like building stuff on survival with fair difficulity, you want this game.If you love medieval era, you want this game.Want a trebuchet? Balista? Siege tower? You can make it in this game. And experience the glorious and often funny bugs with physics when shooting a deer.Like engineering gates, moving bridges, whole clock mechanisms? - you want to play this game.Ever wanted to make a stronghold block-by-block? You want this game.Loved the stronghold series? You want this game.If you just like building things, you want this game.Game works pretty good, but it's obvious that with a 2500+ blocks it wont run fast and smooth.Loved space engineers, but want a more "traditional" experience? Play it. It's great.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								With the understanding that it's early access (I dislike how often the steam community needs to be reminded of this), I certainly recommend this game.  The physics and destruction technologies are astounding, and worth the price just by themselves in my opinion.That being said, I usually spend most of my time building contraptions or weapons, and less frequently have I engaged in survival gameplay or multiplayer.  Survival does not yet feel finished, but I think it's headed in the right direction.  The multiplayer that I have engaged in doesn't seem to have any glaring problems.But I feel that where this game really shines is when you come up with some crazy new idea for a weapon or portcullis or something, build it, and it actually WORKS more or less like you expect it to.  That's rare for a physics engine.I built an extendible bridge the other day that opens with a scissor-like motion, all just by turning a crank.  And it actually worked!  I've read some complaints that it's hard to put stuff together, so I guess there might be a learning curve.  Personally, I thought it was pretty intuitive and well designed.  The controls to rotate blocks could be better, though.As far as performance issues go, I have a $1500 rig, which I feel is a sort of upper-middle-range price (not ludicrous, certainly).  I play on pretty much maxed-out settings at 2560x1440 and I don't usually see the fps drop below 80.  It hasn't been a problem for me.  I agree that it isn't very optimized yet, though, so if you've got an older or budget build at the moment then the time might not be right to buy.  Also, my build is Intel/Nvidia based, and I don't know how much that affects this game (there was some question about that in other reviews).Anyway, building contraptions (not to mention castles) makes me happy, so if you're anything like me, you ought to like this game.  And I'm very impressed with what they've accomplished with Space Engineers, so I'm pretty excited about what Medieval Engineers will become.  It's kept up a pretty good development pace so far.TL;DR:Survival and other aspects are unfinished, but the physics-based engineering/inventing dynamic even just in creative mode makes this game worth the price. [LAST REMINDER - THIS GAME IS EARLY ACCESS]

content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								I bought this game a year ago and thought "Hey this looks cool! Biweekly updates means it will be a hundred times better after a year!" Hell no. I stopped playing a year ago because it was terribly optimised and I could barely run it on a good computer. And let’s say even if I had a bad computer in a year it should have run the same if not better right? Again Hell No! I opened it up and it was VERY laggy and worse than before. I loaded a world for 10 minutes and then when I got in it would lag and freeze at the lowest settings! Then the screen turned white and I could do nothing. To stop this I had to shut down my computer... Twice, I tried twice and the second time it turned white from the get go. So even biweekly updates could not save this game because it is more of a wreck then when I bought it a year ago. Maybe in another year it might be ok. And also the building is insanely difficult and unless you have a degree in architecture or physics never expect to make a catapult or castle its way to hard and requires lots of knowledge that is too complex for a simple game to require, I could not make a castle with catapults and a nice design if I actually played for that year!

content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Did you play LEGO as a kid?Did you yearn for your LEGO men to smash everything you built in a war?This is the game for you then.I hardly ever write reviews, but seeing as there is a surge in negative reviews based entirly on this 'paid mod' debacle, I figured it was only moral to throw in my "Yes" vote.I don't intend to 'buy mods'; but that doesnsn't stop this from already being a highly entertaining title, not to mention educational.I've learned more about machinery and physics in a few hours with ME; than I have in school, ever.Machinery is not limited to 'realistic and existing' types of builds either; if you can imagine it, you can prolly work out how to build it; for the most part.This game is well worth the money, even at this early point, and weekly updates by Keen constantly keeps fresh content flowing, and makes each week a mini Christmas.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game sucks. It should NOT of been released. laggy, buggy, half the time I cant even load a game before it crashes. It would take WEEKS to accomplish ANYTHING in this game. I have tried everything and it is still crap. The creative mode was NOT made for creating. You cant even stop moving when you want to.. its like your character is running on ice, you try to stop but he keeps going. I tried to make a tower, made the tower first and then tried to put stairs in. wouldnt let me. So fine, I deleted a few blocks before the tower fell down, and broke the base blocks. I tried to delete the broken ones to put new ones.. wouldnt let me. Tried to just put new ones, wouldnt let me. So I said screw it and just went to a different part to start all over.. I made the stairs first and THEN tried to make the tower.. BUT THE WALLS DONT CONNECT TO THE STAIRS. So you have a tower with stairs in the middle and a HUGE gap between the walls and stairs. Wow. DO NOT BUY, if your into this kind of game, please, save yourself the money and just buy minecraft. So much easier.. and more fun.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								Keen are excellent liars.Very skilled.They make the claim that SE and ME have two diffrent design teams, yet claim that when one has a patch that benefits both games since they are made on the same engine that things can be moved over.For example they claimed adding planets in Space Engineers would help Medieval Engineers.Despite planets being in for several months ME planet is still a static world not a planet.The most damning evidence however is the updates.When SE goes into bug fixing so does ME, despite SE now moving into Beta (the time for bug fixes) and ME is still in alpha (the time for adding content).However it seems SE and ME have the same team working on both games, when ME came out their was a clear lack of updates for SE, when they started working on Planets for SE, ME updates moved to bugfixing and smaller stuff like "siege".When ME first came out SE moved into a period of Bugfixes that hardly fixed any bugs.Now both games are in a perioud of bugfixing and I'm supposed to be gullible enough to believe the fixes for ME aren't the fixes they made for SE carried over since they share the same engine?Keen invested 10 million of "his own money" into a company that is supposed to create "TRUE" Ai.I have a hard time believing that with a 10 million investment with programmers who are not able to program a decent engine without massive memory leaks and broken multiplayer are supposed to accomplish something that more competent and funded programmers declare is impossible given current technological limitations?Someone give me what ever he is smoking.
